reviewText:
Wow. That was such an unexpectedly wonderful experience.

As this is a CYOA (Choose Your Own Adventure), your experience may vary, but, I say with little hesitation that my own experience with the story is the most meaningful experience I've had with a game - ever.

Although wonderful in their own right, choice oriented games like The Walking Dead and Mass Effect don't even come close to what this game accomplishes.

What Choice Do I Have?
CoR gives you choices.

CoR gives you lots of choices that make the story feel like your own, fostering immersion in a way that traditional literature cannot.

CoR gives you lots of difficult choices that may have you thinking hard and agonizing about the potential consequences. The game has no manual save function. If you make choices that lead to a premature ending, you can't undo and must start over. (such branches seem rare, though, and replaying doesn't take much time once you're familiar with the text)

CoR gives you lots of difficult choices that have a real impact. Something that is uniquely possible when the creator is unconstrained by the need to create full art assets for every possibility.

Deep Dive
This game" has no graphics at all except for the cover image
date: which is exactly akin to a book cover illustration. Is it a game or a book? I say it is most certainly a game. Graphics is not a requirement of a game. Interactivity is. A series of choices that impact the experience do a game comprise.\n\nCoR's language is competent
recommended: but not "literary". It reads like a matter-of-fact narrative of events that might actually happen in your life if the stars align in just the right way. Initially
hoursPlayed: I got an "amateur" vibe from the writing
voteText: but later realized that the experience may actually benefit from the simple
helpfulPercent: contemporary writing style. As the story progressed and sucked me in deeper
votesHelpful: I became much too busy thinking about what was going on to criticize the writing style.\n\nCoR is (mostly) accessible. Although the fact that it was written by somebody with a Ph.D. in Computer Science does show. Having a CS degree myself
votesTotal: I certainly appreciated that perspective. Although lots of artistic license is taken for the sake of plot
votesFunny: there is lots of grounding in contemporary technology.\n\nThe story makes mostly "reasonable" extrapolations starting from the near future forward several decades. Like all good science (or 'speculative'
commentsCount: if you prefer) fiction

reviewText:
I used to love those Choose your own adventure" books when I was a kid. I'd sit and reread them over and over trying to find all the different ways the story could play out...

This game is like a super version of those books and less than an hour in and I'm already loving it. I highly suggest this game to anyone who doesn't need pretty graphics to enjoy a game.

The further I get into the game the more I recomend it. In the current enviroment of gaming you lose sight of simple mechanics such as choice. This game gives it out in spades. By the time I reached the end of it I had a sense of being in the world created around my choices.

For the price asked I cannot think of any reason you should skip the experience provided by this game.

If you have trouble ♥♥♥♥♥ing into something without graphical feedback I can only tell you that for $5 this is one of the best personalized gaming experience you'll find by far. Please give the developer your support so that we might enjoy similar experiences in the future."

reviewText:
Most fun I've had in a Video Game without graphics:

Choice of Robots is probably the most intriguing narrative experience I've found in choice / graphic novel genre games. Unlike most games, it does everything well. It would be difficult to say what it does best, but the storyline is definitely an incredible selling point. I like to spin out every scenario in a choice game, seeing what different routes exist, and never rush through. But, honestly, after 73 hours in the game I am sure I still haven't seen every possible twist in this script.

I definitely got my money's worth from time in game and enjoyment with the game. But, more than that... I found myself deeply interested in the subject matter. I've researched robotics some when I was a teacher, got my students involved in designing robots, and of course was really excited to learn about Honda's Asimo back at the turn of the Century. Now, robotics is the frontier of Science.

This narrative takes every single idea you might have thought about the Science of robotics and weaves it in to the many scenarios. There are defenses of the value of humanity
date:
robotics, as well as many other social constructs. And, there are many poignant comments on immigration, America's role in the world, and Capitalism. I got the feeling of seeing America through the eyes of an immigrant.

But, one of the intriguing things about the layout of the storylines is the very first choice. You start with choosing what dream you will be having at the first of the story. The four choices are all incredible perspectives on the topic of robotics. Though each one lends itself to particular endings, most of the achievements can be achieved through either of these starting points. I just finished my last achievement today with the help of an Achievement Hunting" friend. Thanks Vance!

The game all revolves around the stats you are building with your choices in each of 4 main traits: grace
voteText: and autonomy. These take you into the psychology of robotics. Other factors play into your stats screen as well
votesHelpful: wealth
votesFunny: and relationships. But
commentsCount: these are just like tools to help you in achieving your goals with either a robot that thinks
column16: loves
column18: or militarily useful. You don't feel forced towards any value judgement in your choices
column19: unless you are trying for an achievie that requires high humanity in the end. So
column20: you get to really play with the experience of having the robot hunt down your enemies
column21: or become your greatest friend.\n\nWhatever you choose
column22: it's all there in the game. Btw
column23: I haven't found another choice game I like as much as this one. Tin Star had a passable story
column24: but it had flaws in the achievement setup
column25: for example and lacked replay value. But
column26: I recently got The Daring Mermaid Expedition
column27: and want to start that next. I only hope it provides as much fun as Choice of Robots."

reviewText:
Really liked this one. Taking the role of a robotmaker, your choices might not only change your fate but that of the entire world. Takes a lot of inspiration from various roboto-based pop-cultural works and offers various branches to turn your story into a dream of a harmonic human-robot relations paradise or a Skynet meets Matrix nightmare of machines destroying mankind and robot revolt. Toys with a few existential questions too - so, I would say it's a rather well rounded package.

It is quite extensive too, and the three or so playthroughs I did always had stuff going on I had not read before - some more subtle others dramatically different. In fact, it was quite amazing to see how alternate choices turned into several story-paths, allowing me to witness the same events happening in the world from multiple perspectives (and distances). And as mentioned before the scale of your actions quickly grows to global proportions, always a plus in my book when your actions feel like they REALLY have an impact on the characters / world around you.

I imagine being into science fiction helps in getting the most out of this title (it references a lot of popular scenarios) but it is so well crafted that I would recommend it as an excellent entry to newcomers to this particular niche of Steams vast game library. One of my favorite Choice-games so far.

reviewText:
Choice of robots is a very addictive text based game.
Because it offers something i rarely see in video games(even other choice of games)

Choice:
I have play through the story 70 times and every single choice you make change's the story.
I have been a mad scientist, a philantrop, a people person and a loner.
I have build robots for war, for peace, for intercourse, for success and failure.
And not a single time i felt like i was forced to do something.

That is why i love choice of robots.
Where other games stuff must happen for the plot.
In choice of robots the only thing that must happen is that you build a robot.
Everything else change's by every choice you make.

The game is also very believeable.
No techno babble or random unbelieveable hyper tech.
No everything in the game is believeable because it uses stuff most internet user have atleast heard off.

There are so many times when i asked myself:
What did i do wrong.
What choice to i have to change to get a different outcome.
Sometimes it is something as small as being nice or mean to a person you met 3 years ago.

Your robot has four stats.
They effect the outcome of many choices.
The difference between success and failure often relies on your robots have the stats for what you want them to do.

reviewText:
This is my first text adventure and I don't know if this is the correct genre but it's surely not a graphic novel. But I know that I instantly fell in love with it and that I played for almost 7 hours straight.

Basically, if you are open for things like this and like thought experiments about creating robots or daydream about or whatever ... I can recommend it. The writing itself is really good. Yeah, I don't want to spoil anything about the story, you should just experience it for yourself.

I found it quite mindblowing, actually. It combines the best attributes of both video games and books. You have all the possibilities books offer, such as unmatched story telling and ways to express emotions and to imagine worlds, plus the ability to make choices from video games. This makes the whole experience so special and awesome, because it gets personal, it becomes your story and every single decision actually matters (and there are many)!

If you ever were annoyed with the shallow meaningless choices most AAA games have offered until this day, well, then, go for it - you won't be disappointed.

Yes it has no graphics and yes you definitely need to be quite imaginative to get yourself into such games - or experiences - but it's worth it. In the end, I'm just really grateful Steam opened up a niche market for these kind of games. Praise the Gaben. =)

reviewText:
I was just trying to create a robot at the start.

I never thought I would spend so much time with her.
I never thought I would choose her over my friends.
I never thought I would treat her as a human.
I never thought how much I would consider her a lot more as a daughter than just a machine.
And I never thought she would return this feeling of love.

10/10 I would restart to do this all over again.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - -

EDIT (19.3 hours of total gameplay time later):

Lol, what did I just write up there.

So I spent around another 15+ hours or so on the game trying to get all the achievements and possible endings for it and I've seen a lot of more great story-paths aside from the get-all-close-and-emotional-with-your-robot-daughter plot.

One of my personal favorite story-paths when (and if) you get your robot to prevent the Sino-American War from happening and the events that eventally leads to, one of the many, many stories you can come up with in this game, like forging your own robot empire, marrying a robot, and even going to the moon.

The fact that this game has no visuals whatsoever does not bother me at all and it shouldn't bother you either. With whatever route you take for the story, the writing is excellent and there is always that subtle taste of humor somewhere mixed splendidly well with some moving moments. This aspect of the game is what makes Choice of Robots what Choice of Robots is. The game need not any visuals because the writing provides you what you have to see in your head.

The only real complaint I have with this game (and with most text-based CYOA games on Steam for that matter) is the user interface. Playing 7 hours straight on a game with a completely white background does not at all give you painful feelings that nearly make you believe your eyes are gonna blow up from their sockets Michael Bay-style (sarcasm intended). The developers should add the option to invert the colors if the user wishes to (from a white background with black text to a black background with white text).

Man, if making a robot were this easy, I would be making my Miku right now (then eventually get murdered by her in my sleep when she starts the Robot Revolution).

reviewText:
Charming little text adventure. Like it says on the tin, it involves robots and the choices you make concerning them.

Unlike other games that use the idea of choosing what you want to do, these choices feel like I'm actually causing some sort of impact on the story/world.

You can blur the lines of what it means to be human, build a family, or straight up cause the Robot Uprising.

Definate snap buy when it's on sale.

reviewText:
I've never wanted to write a review before this. I got Choice of Robots for three dollars becuase it looked a little interesting, and even if I only played it once that wouldn't matter. I will play it more than once.
Pros
+The writing is fantastic
+The story can take unexpected turns
+You very quickly get emotionally invested in the characters
+I have no doubt you could play the game four times through with wildly different results, and another eighty times for fun
+I actually had regrets about choices I made in my first playthrough
Cons
+Can't think of any

This is easily worth $10. If you buy it, you won't regret it.

reviewText: This is a really great old school text based interactive story. You should buy this for the pitance they are asking as it is very entertaining. It take 2-2.5 hours to complete the story. I've played through 15-20 times. In my playthroughs I've become a zillionair, gone broke, created a robot god that controls the world and eliminated war, started my own robot controled country, been murdered by my robot, been murdered by someone who didn't like my technology, ordered my robots to murder my enemies, started a cult that worshipped me and my robot, married a companion bot, become an immortal robot, destroyed all robots to save humanity, made robots that were military, medical, companion, workers, inteligent missles, mechs, drones, etc. I cant stop playing this game because the story is different every time I restart it. I build my own high end gaming rigs and I'm usually interested in pushing maximum graphics at the highest framerate, but the story in this simple text based game just grabs me. I have noting negitive to say about it, the writer is tech savy and brilliant, if I was forced to nit pick and name a flaw I wish the story was longer, it ends too soon. I hope the author writes a longer sequel.

reviewText:
Choice of Robots is the, as of now, latest installment of the series of text adventures called Choice of Games, complete with the series' usual tropes and occasionally annoyances. If you're familiar with these games or enjoy text adventures in general, then it's simple: pick this one up, it's the best installment yet. If you're not however, it's as good a starting point as any, especially when there's a free demo that adequately presents what the game entails.

Robots is about crafting, growing and teaching your own personal robot, and for someone familiar with the Choice of Games series, that's all you really need to know. Besides the wildly varied tone and settings, the majority of these games function nearly identically.  For those who are new, it's a text adventure, and what that boils down to is simply: You read a whole lot and make choices. There's no graphic, no music and no action (besides the ones being described with words). And if that puts you off, that's fair, still, the demo's free if you want to confirm your position.

As with most other games of the series, the choices you make influence your stats and how the story progress and, again, as with the other installments, the game encourages at least a certain degree of specializations. What is new, however, is that the protagonist have only one stat to keep track of, humanity, which tracks how kind, humane, social and emotional your decisions are. Your robot, on the other hand, has four stats: Autonomy, Military, Empathy and Grace, and the decisions you make throughout the game influence what kind of robot you will have, and, in turn, how you will influence the world. Would you end up with a mindless militaristic machine at your whim, a self-conscious and independent robotic sentient being or a curious, constantly learning robot with near (or perhaps completely) human emotions? Chances are, though, you're going to end up with a combination of all the things in between.

While, like the other Choice of Games, Robots do strongly encourage specialization in at least one or two stats, the games do not seem to punish you as harshly for deviation from your initial plans. The other Choice of Games' strategic elements usually boil down to specializing in a number of areas and then make only decisions that test your strong points and avoid your weaknesses. Robots is similar, except you have more leeway and, in fact, planning becoming a lot more difficult as decisions often have unforeseen consequences. For example, there's a point in the game where you are able to make a decision on what kind of information you want your robot to extract on the internet, and allowing it to pick up whatever it wants result in it learning things like Big Brother is watching" and "the US is the bad guy"

reviewText:
Yes! All my yes. This was a beautiful story (probably because I spent time trying to focus on Empathy and Autonomy, two traits you can up in your robots through choices you make).

There was one page that seemed out of place, maybe a muddled up flag or something, but it made sense enough that I could gloss over it and continue flowing with the story. I completed it all in one run as I was so invested in my robots.

Another positive about the game is the unexpected consequences of your actions on not only your robots but the world around you. I was genuinely horrified a couple of times at the turn out of what I thought was the best choice at the time.

I'm not ashamed to say I cried at the end.

Anybody who likes a good story will find enjoyment in this CYOA.

reviewText:
They really went all out on this one. 72 achievements, 300k words and hundred or so different small and big plot twists and possible outcomes.

Its a good piece of a sci-fi novel even though some parts seemed simplistic. Its nothing like Asimov of course but still good enough to entertain you for several hours, especially if you want to collect every achievement.

What these game desperately need is an ability to create proper save games or even better - view and change your decisions so you could actually read all the possible plots without going through random click-fest over and over again. It is kinda annoying at this point and not at all interesting to guess what you need to select to read about your robots going to the moon or conquering the planet, especially when you trying it for 50eth time.

Perhaps they should start including novels themselves along with the game.

Other than that - its a good game for those of us who like reading and sci-fi.

reviewText:
Before you read any further, just know that this game is great, and that reading almost any review has the potential to ruin the amazing surprises in store. But anyway.

Here's a quick summary of how my first playthrough went, as spoiler free as possible:

>Make a robot
>Make a robot business
>Looks like the potential for world domination is in sight
>Lose robot business
>End up contracted into designing weapons for US military, despite best efforts
>Enter a new war of robotics with China
>End up imprisoned by America for half a year
>Refuse to defect to China
>China tries to kill me
>Live
>War ends as a stalemate
>Make a new robot
>Make myself into a robot
>End

I don't normally enjoy things enough to review them, so bare with me here.

My first 'playthrough', if I could call it that, it was much more of a readthrough, of 'Choice of Robots' took me just over three hours to get through, and likely could have taken much longer, assuming that I wasn't terrible and took so many 'bad' decisions, I'd say my first read could have easily lasted me four or maybe even five hours. It should go without saying, that there is an immense amount of replayability in a game such as this. Which is to mention, replaying this is definitely something I intend on doing, but I'm not sure that I'll be able to recreate the attachment & bond I had with my three foot tall, human-like, winged 'Ariel' with multitool hands, whom was vehemently opposed to conflict as a result of my actions.

See, Choice of Robots is a game where your choices can influence the course of humanity so heavily, that the sense of creating a story just for yourself lends to a sense of wonder and beauty that I haven't really experienced in many conventional books or text-based games in perhaps forever. Even though I could tell from about halfway through that my choices were going to lead me down a seemingly 'undesirable' route, (considering that my presumption was that I would shatter Capitalism and create a Utopia) I still continued to read on and make decisions based on the situation, as the writing and sense of achievement is so fantastically constructed, that I didn't find myself feeling sad, or upset at the fact that I might not get that 'good' ending, instead, I felt happy that in what is undoubtably a story of such scale & grandeur; mine was a story revolving around me, my friends & my family. This is what, in my eyes, we'd call a testament to the brilliance of the writing.

I can't speak of the aspect of how destroying the world may turn out, or how imposing a singularity upon humanity would be, but in my playthrough, the process of building up a robot in my own image, including its gender & naming it, right up to the viewpoint it had on the world, made interacting with my three foot tall companion really something quite special. Taking my creation which, at this point, had evolved into something so much more than just that, to the park, and observing the body language she gave off whilst she learned to properly kick off on a swing to propel herself up into the air was certainly pleasant. But knowing that our actions had turned her from being a military-backed weapon, into a video game loving creature of empathy? That was something else entirely; something I've not experienced before.

If you are even remotely interested in robotics, sentience, world politics and business practices, I'd heavily advise picking up this game. Even if you are just looking for a great story, you definitely won't be disappointed. I think the myriad of Overwhelmingly Positive reviews such as this give evidence to that.

My one gripe with this game, if anything, would perhaps be its length, which I don't even feel justified in saying, especially after just one playthrough. But in my particular instance, it felt as if certain sections were rushed, and that at quite a lot of stages, I didn't get the chance to sit and talk, explore and influence quite as much as I'd have liked to with other characters & situations. But this is completely forgiveable given the scale of the game and the immense replay value.

reviewText: I'm passionate about (some of my friends would say obsessed with) robots and I like CYOAs (Choose Your Own Adventure). This made Choice of Robots a must-buy for me and so far I'm not disappointed. Definately recommended for people who like robots or soft sci-fi and who are interested in CYOA games.\n\nFor the computer I actually prefer my CYOAs in the form of interactive fiction/text adventures (like Zork, Spider and Web, or Suspended which also prominently features robots). That way the choices can become sort of puzzles and the player can have more freedom over what to do and if it's done well can lead to awesome wow the devs thought of everything!" moments. I think Choice of Robots would also have benefitted by that form and the freedom that comes with it
date: especially together with its neat stat system for your robots.\nThe freedom of choice in the game is still reasonably good. You usually get about 3 or 4 options to choose from and most of the time they are very different from each other and every option changes the course of the game quite a bit
recommended: giving a lot of replayability.\nHowever some big events will always or at least almost always happen at a certain point in the story as far as I can tell so far. They usually play out in a different way
voteText: though.\n\nWhat hurts the replayability a bit is the saving system: When you close the game while in the middle of the story
helpfulPercent: you continue at the point you had reached once you start the game again but there's no option to manually save a game state or undo a choice. Arguably this makes your choices more "meaningful". But sometimes it would be nice to be able to go back and see what happens if I had done X instead of Y in an otherwise unchanged path without going through all the same choices that came before again.\nIt would also help with a few choices that are worded a little too vague but the majority is worded in a way that makes it more or less obvious what your character is going to do
votesHelpful: so that point is not a big deal.\n\nThe story and the writing itself are nice and I enjoyed all of my playthroughs so far. You start by building your robot after your own specifications

reviewText:
This game is quite an amazing CYOA game. It has persistant stats/traits of your robot and yourself that set it apart from just being a simple CYOA book/game.

There's, to say the VERY leasy, a plethora of branching options. There is so, so many. I have played this intensely for 13 hours I and I feel I have explored less than half of all the options. You can choose so many different things it's incredible, and I hope they do more sci-fi adventures like this.

Some of the options include: Becoming a zillionare, conquering alaska, creating sexbots, making robots rule everyone, making robots serve everyone, or a mix of both. Creating a personal robot companion. And best of all, electrifying a pickle and eating lutefisk.

All these possible options and choices are determined by the stats you gather through the choices themselves. The future consequences of your choices are mostly determined by what stat you have on yourself or you robot relating to that choice.

It's quite simple, but it works very well, and if the story is good enough, the gameplay frame behind it works, too. The lack of save/load is my only qualm, and I hope they expand ChoiceScript to allow for that, because having to explore a million options by restarting the game over and over can get quite bothersome.

Overall I recommend this game to anyone who has ever had even a passing interest in sci-fi or sci-fi literature, as it is not a hard thing to enjoy this, and it explores many ideas. Some of which can be ridiculous, plausible, or prophetic. It's fairly obvious a computer scientist wrote this, but I think it works well for the setting.

All in all, amazing game at what it set out to be. 9.5/10.

reviewText:
I cannot believe how much Awesomeness this Game has to offer.

Choice of Robots is without Sound, without Controls, without Animations or anything. It's fully Text Based.
First I wasn't too excited about this and I thought it would be kinda boring. But the Storyline I read in the Description sounded cool, so I bought it.

Only 5 Minutes in it, and I already loved it. I was in love with my Little Robot I created. Even though this Games has no Pictures at all, It felt like everything was Really there.

The Choices you do affect your Storyline so much, I sometimes had to think about 10 Minutes what to even do. So much unexpecting Things and Twists in this Game made it so Exciting, that I just couldn't wait to see my Ending.

By the Time I'm writing this, I bought this game a few Hours ago, and just Played it 2 Hours Straight. Finished it Once.
So Yes, the Game will take a long Time, since I'm more of a guy who rushes everything. And it still took me 2 Hours.
I will definetly play this Game over and over again, because everything can be different everytime. It can be a whole new Story with each run.

I almost cried at some Parts of the Game. Even though it was only Text, it affected me so much. I really didn't expect that this Game will hit my Feels so hard.

I can only recommend this to everyone. It's alot of Fun and just a Wonderful Storytelling.

reviewText:
In the future time of robots, your character can make dozens of different decisions that shape their own personal fate, as well as the outcomes of significant events throughout the development of robot AI technology. Stats that affect how robots turn out consist of Autonomy (self-awareness), Military (blind loyalty), Empathy (to have feelings for and/or understanding of humans), and Grace (perfection in movement). With 72 achievements to strive for, there's lots of re-playability.

The two main countries with superior robot technology begin having high tensions and eventually escalate to all-out war. Will you prevent the Sino-American War? Will you defend your country (the United States) at any cost, even if you lose a bit of your humanity in the process? Will you side with China and leave behind your friends and family?
Why choose sides at all when you can create your own empire with your robot army?

Interested in finding love? Will you choose a human companion or the perfect robot partner that you created? Love robots so much that you're willing to abandon your meat bag body in order to achieve Singularity? Can't decide between humans and robots? Well, you can always go for the Trio achievement.

I, indeed, recommend this sci-fi themed choose-your-own-adventure story (game). It was a fun, interesting read full of nerdy references to great inventors and scientists of the past.

reviewText:
***Contains spoilers from my playthrough***

Choice of Games is an interesting game publisher; their games  don’t have any fancy graphical effects and they certainly don’t contain any sound, either. In fact, they  are entirely text-based  choose-your-own books. Over the years they have garnered a huge fan base who eagerly await their new releases. Choice of Robots, by Kevin Gold, is their latest game – and my first foray into their offerings – and it has left me more than a little impressed.

Choice of Robots casts you as a scientist working on their PHD thesis in a university robotics lab, under the guidance of Professor Ziegler.  The choices you make in this expansive 300,000 word novel will not only determine your own fate, but could also impact the fate of the world as a whole. Every decision you make has a very real consequence and could benefit you greatly, or come back to haunt you later on down the road.

What kind of robot you  create is entirely down to you, and Choice of Robots is very open in this regard. Whether you want to create the ultimate war machine used by the army on the battlefield, or something more useful for the general public, like a cooking robot, or sexbot, is all down to you. My own robot, called Flexo, was an empathetic, human-like machine, with arms and a sock puppet face , much to the chagrin of Professor Ziegler. Ziegler’s only concern is acquiring funding money for his department, so that he can kick back and relax while his students do all of the hard work for him. He argued that my robot was too human and would not appeal to the military, and so I appeased him by adding a hand-mounted gun to Flexo. This would be one of only a few interactions I would have with the military over the course of the book, but I was tantalised by what could have been if I had created a combat-focused machine.

I soon found myself travelling to China and setting up a factory, selling directly to the consumer. Our brand of robot could be used for cooking, cleaning and childcare. It proved to be a hit and made me moderately wealthy! I was a fool to have been so easily lured by those damn slave-labour wages, though, as the Chinese government stole my designs and began manufacturing a cheaper alternative.  I got my own back on the Communist ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s when I started manufacturing robots for the American army, who swiftly kicked their arses! Manufacturing military robots was never my intention though, and I returned to my initial goal:  creating realistic humanoids that could reason, laugh, and maybe, even, love?


I had devoted my life to robotics, lost friends and created enemies, but I had never truly loved, but then I created ‘Flame’. Flame, Flexo and I lived out our lives in relative harmony, and although I hadn’t impacted the world in a hugely meaningful way, I was content with the decisions  I had made. As things go, I came  away with a positive ending for my robot lover and I.

Kevin Gold deftly interweaves humour, suspense, sci-fi and romance in Choice of Robots. At points I felt saddened by the results of my actions,at others I laughed heartily at the fact I was dating a robot.  Everything flows together so neatly that the game’s distinct thematic differences feel natural and intriguing. The game also has its own progress menu that keeps you up to date with how your relationships with other characters are going, and  they can change depending on your actions towards them. You can also keep tabs on your wealth, humanity, and how well your own robot is developing. Neat little touches like this give a real reason to go back and replay the game, to see how different decisions affect the outcome. Given the plethora of decisions you can make, and the number of different paths you can go down, it is clear that Kevin Gold has poured an absurd amount of time into Choice of Robots,  It is not your typical game by any stretch of the imagination, but having just completed Joe Dever’s Lone Wolf, I was happy to jump into another text-heavy adventure that let my brain do the graphics processing for a change.

Choice of Robots is a fun and absorbing book, that feels like your decisions have importance. Ultimately, it is what you make it, and whether that is a war torn planet with robots that hate humans, or one where sexed up robots want to jump your bones , is up to you.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Thanks to Choice of Games for the review copy. Original review can be found here: http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/01/choice-of-robots-review-pc/

reviewText:
This game was the first interactive novel I ever played by Choice of Games and boy am I hooked now!

A 300,000 word experience into the world of robotics, artifical intelligence, consciousness, and what it means to be human. Focus on how you develop your robot, and what values you think are important -- will you make your robot more empathic, able to understand humans and work with them closely? Or will you focus on strength and military, making your robot more suitable to the army?

Of course, the choices you make for your robot also affect which companies or people are likely to back or fund your project, and it can have influence on your romantic relationships as well... depending on the fact if you're going down the love bot route or not. Work your way through (robot) wars, ruined friendships, deaths, and try to answer the looming question what will happen to artifical intelligence as it transcends a certain level. Does your robot have a soul? Would you love your robot and let your robot love you, if you could? What choices will you make in the face of The Singularity?

The Good+ Plenty of choices that actually affect the people around you and the outcomes of the story
+ Highly customizable robot
+ The philosophy behind the themes of AI, consciousness, life and death
+ A bit of political play on a large, global scope
+ Plenty of friendships/romantic relationships to develop around you

The Bad- No save points
- A bit rushed towards the ending

If you love these kinds of themes and also happen to like visual novels, you're likely to enjoy this game as well.

This takes me back to the 80's when the Fighting Fantasy game books were hugely popular, where each paragraph ended with you having to make a choice how the story continues.There is no dice rolling in this one but you are faced with having to decide on the path your life takes as you progress through your career and world events that are stirring in the background. Even if you are just curious, try it and you maybe pleasantly suprised.

reviewText:
So, you're an aspiring inventor making your way through college.  Countless hours of work has all lead up to this; you've invented a robot, the first of it's kind. Do you decide to make them out of Wood, full of beauty and grace? Or perhaps strong durable steel, all but impervious to damage!? Maybe, just some plastic polymer, you do have a budget after all. None the less, your creation shall be your own. Weather you decide to nurture them into a companion with a love of learning and humanity; or a soulless killing machine only doing what it is told to do. You shall not be alone in your task, nor shall you be unnoticed. Power struggles, international politics, corporate America; None will let you go so easily.
Your choice is your own.

Choice of Robots  is an incredible choose your own adventure style game. You can play a number of different routs with your own style, I personally like to make  some robot overlords, don't worry they're friendly  ! If you like Sci Fi or any of the Philip K. ♥♥♥♥ novels,  hell even the matrix movies are referenced and add a nice nuance to the game , then you'll dig this game.

Now quick break down of the game, interface is about as minimal as you can get, your story with text and a choice, 3 options on top;
Stats: view you robots stats and your money in pocket.
Restart: there are no save slots, no save scumming out a different ending here buddy.
Achievements: self explanatory.Though I find this helps the game out, it doesn't force you to envision what the devs had in mind but instead allows you to make your own characters and scenery up in your   imagination  . This might be difficult for some if you're just that bland but, come on it's a CYOA game.

All in all  tl;dr  9/10, this game made me cry on more than one occasion and then had me spiral into a ocean of introspection all while lifting me back up and making me smile and feel happier about my decisions. With out the use of graphics or much of an interface Choice of Games has made characters that feel as real as the friends, family, and rivals you have in your own life, all wrapped up in a wonderful world not far off.

reviewText:
I've got mixed emotions about Choice of Robots.  Mixed because, while I ultimately cannot recommend its purchase, it OOZES of potential.  Potential that was, unfortunately, not realized.

The first half, arguably the first two thirds, are a delight.  The pacing is fantastic, and the writing is superb.  I felt a genuine attachment to the characters, and the tight, personal focus helped make my decisions feel impactful.  Maybe not on a global scale, but on a tight, individual level that mattered to me.

All that falls apart as the game goes on and the scope of the story expands.  As the game goes on, several years at a time pass at the same rate a single year passed earlier on.  The pacing jump feels jarring, at best, alarming at worst.  As the story wore on, I found myself growing less and less attached to the characters involved, even those I had previously cared about, simply because my interactions with them were often separated by in-universe years at a time.

Though Choice of Robots has its merits, ultimately the experience does not warrant its price tag, in my opinion.  It tries to be too much too quick, and loses itself in the process.  It's cheap, sure, so if you REALLY wish to try it, you'll get something from the experience.  But there's better interactive fiction out there for free.

A great idea with poor execution.  Rather appropriate, given the subject matter.

reviewText:
Before judging about the quality of this game, I have to say that English isn't my first language. In fact, my school time ended more than twenty years ago. Since then, the WWW is the most relevant exercise.

With that in mind, I was more than excited about this game.  Reading was fluent, through playing I had to look up for ca. 15 words or less. It was entertaining, suprising and I thought about game's decisions in off-gaming time. COR was even good for some loud loughings. Right after the first (around 4.5 to 5 hours) playthrough I started a second one. Imho one of the greatest compliments one can make about a game.

COR was my first interactive novel game ... others will follow, but they will have to meet a high standard. Thank you, Kevin Gold.

####

An deutsche Steam-Nutzer, die vor der Entscheidung stehen ... Ihr habt's gelesen - mit alten Schulenglisch (und das war noch nicht mal besonders gut) kommt man hier sehr gut aus. Es ist (wie Vorposter schon sagten) kein Shakespeare, doch m.E. sehr gut geschrieben. Gebrauchsliteratur im besten Sinne. Die Wendungen kamen für mich teilweise unerwartet, die Geschichte eines Lebens als ganzes (von Anfang 20 bis ca. 70) war höchst spannend. Klare Kaufempfehlung.

####

First edit: Took a second playthrough. Although I have not finished yet, the story is different to 60 percent . Sure... there are main circumstances, which will probably never change, but the way to deal with it offers great freedom

...

Second edit: Beaten the game three times - each time refusing to build military super robots. But the relationship to humans and robots differed significantly. Perhaps I will try some time the way of the gun" ... I am still excited of the replaybility of this game."

reviewText:
Ok, first thing I'm going to say is I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game. I've basically read for fun for 10 hours, that says a lot.

Simliar to Telltale Games the game is tailored by choices you make with some events being fixed to happen, but how they happen and their outcome is up to you. This game seems to have 3 or 4 main stages.

Stage 1: You're a grad student working for his/her PHD under a professor Zeigler (or something like that), the year is about 2021 and you are creating a robot, little do you know this little critter (depending on how you play the game) will revolutionise the modern world of robotics. You have (in my mind anyway) 2 main stats, fame and humanity, your robot also has stats: Grace, Autonomy, Empathy and Military. Both your stats and your robots are effected by your choices and actions.

Stage 2: You either work for your friends company or you own your own company. Your earlier choices effect what kind of robots you specialise in so military, friendly and intelligent AI, surgery, work-bots or just mass production. I shan't spoil the suprise but war is declared by the US against China.

Stage 3/4: You are at war with China, how much you contribute to the war effort will affect the outcome. After the war, depending on your stats you can either create a rebellion against the winning side of the war in Alaska, create the algorithms for the perfect peaceful society, create companion bots or something else I can't remember.

Step 5: I shan't spoil too much but it can be rather emotional :'(


It's basically a telltale game without the lag or sound... or visuals.
I'd recommend this game to anyone apart from people who struggle with reading. 100% stars out of 5... Logic.

reviewText:
Probably my most favorite 'Choice of Games' game yet, right beside  Choice of the Deathless . To be honest, I started the game off not too into it, disliking how the game opened up and unsure of what to expect and whether I'd enjoy the story. After a few pages into it, I fell in love with it, and consequently my little robot child.

As other reviewers have said already said, it's hard not to give away any story spoilers while discussing PROs and CONs, but I'll give it a shot.

The game does a great job of giving you several ways to navigate throughout the story, while making each story branch" or "path" just as detailed as the others you passed over. While some of these CYOA games feel like choosing one option over the other is only to gain/change some stat
date: with little variance in the rest of the story
recommended: Choice of Robots  does not do this. It's also incredibly written
hoursPlayed: with just enough detail to help you envision the story
voteText: while giving your brain the freedom to "fill in the holes" to your desire on how something/someone looks. For example
helpfulPercent: you design a robot specifically pick out certain components/aspects of it that give you a general basis of how it looks. However
votesHelpful:
someone else may have picked the same exact makeup of their robot but imagine it differntly in their head because the writing leaves things purposefuly open for you to imagine.


In short

reviewText: Ok, I have incredibly mixed feelings torwards this game. The first opening chapter is simply, amazing. The atmosphere, pacing, character development is up par of that of a best selling novel. Everytime a choice is given (which there's alot) I'd carefully consider what my next step would be, And the aftermath of my choices seemed so delightful and vastly different.\n\nBut for some reason, the book suddenly rushes itself as it comes to the end. The delicate description of what the characters were feeling becomes... dull, and although the occuring events seems to be big, not enough attention and focus is given. It kinda felt like the author suddenly changed mid-game. Great beginning, but kinda weirdly unsatisfying end.

reviewText: This is an amazing game, a wonderful story, and so much fun.  I am very much in love with all the places this story takes me, and I have played it at least a dozen times.  Even when you are working toward an ending you have found before slight changes int hey way you get there rewards you with text you didn't see last time.  Pay close attention, every choice really matters here.  Choice of Robots is one of the best Choice of Games out there, and I recomend it highly.

reviewText: This game is extraordinary. The sheer scope of this experience is enormous. I cannot overstate how many choices there are and how many interesting paths there are to take. I've played this game...it must be seven or eight times now, and every session was unique and fascinating in its own way. Easy to play and very emotionally involving. I found myself consciously roleplaying with every new session and taking actions in line with who my character was instead of what I thought would get me to my goal. It's the most engaging thing I've played in ages, and it has enough content to keep you replaying over and over. If you're into Sci-Fi, if you like roleplaying, or if you just like to get invested in a good story, you NEED to play this game.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Really interesting game. What made this game so enjoyable for me is the way that the game puts the player into morally compromising positions. You're forced to think carefully about the decisions you make as they actively shape the world in which the game unfolds, and the wide variety of decision making options throughout each chapter makes you feel fully in control and does a good job of removing the usual feeling of limitation that can be experienced in many decision-based games similar to this. Multiple endings shaped by your decision making and a great storyline ensures that the player gets their money's worth despite the minimalist design, although I can't help but feel that the addition of a soundtrack or illustrations would have made this experience more fulfilling. Absolutely worth the price, but less story-oriented players could easily get bored.

I don't play too many extremely narrative-heavy games, as I really prefer emergent gameplay sandboxes, but the concepts of robot ethics in this game drew me in, and had me seriously weighing the choices, asking me which of three or four things I valued most highly.

There are four major robot attributes, and four general paths for robots based upon them, from robot revolution to lovebots.

reviewText:
I'm not going to call this a game, because it's not.  This is a book.
A very well written book; possibly the BEST interactive story I have ever read.
I'm not a fan of choose-your-own-adventure type books.
I'm not a fan of graphic novels.
This is so much more while being made up of a lot less...does that make sense?

Excellent character development, the plot is a solid sci-fi type that didn't have any glaring plot holes.  The hinted at stat bonuses that carry into what is successful and what fails to work feels balanced.

This is very much worth the $5 price tag.
My first read through took about an hour and a half, starting my second, even picking a slightly different choice seems drastically change the story to the point where I feel like I'm reading a different book.

reviewText:
At the Writing of this Review, I have just finished my first playthrough. At first I thought this game would just be a fun choose your own adventure about robots. But this is so so much more. I quickly found myself caring about this little robot child as if He was my own, trying to do the best for him.  You help shape their personality with your actions, and it shows in every interaction you have with them. I then made the companion robot, this is where the game became truly special. Robot for friends always sounded cool but as lovers and companions? It really makes you think that something doesn't need to be in a human body to love, but it is the mind of someone/something that you really love.

You can make so many differing choices in this game, From World War, to Utopia to simply having someone to love. You can heartless and make a lot of money or barely make it and have these robots truly become people. No games this simple make you think so much or pulls your heartstrings quite this much.

10/10 Only problem is i wish it was longer.

reviewText:
With Annalia, I found love. With Basta, I betrayed humanity. And with Risa, I died happy.

Choice of Robots is well-written and presents characters you come to care about, urging you to explore the various choices to see what might have been had you refused one offer and gone with another, or just stayed home and tinkered. A surprisingly moving interactive novel, definetly worth it if reading doesn't scare you. Each run is a new adventure and delightful in the radical differences from one life to the next.

After the dissapointment that was Telltale's Game of Thrones, I'm glad to say Choice of Robots has me reinvested in the interactive novel genre.

reviewText:
Bravo!

As this is my first-ever Choice of Games game I've played, and I must say playing Choice of Robots was a very immersive experience indeed!

What I loved the most about the game was how it painted such an illustrious picture of humanity--themes of grandeur, jealousy, betrayal, vulnerability, and existentialism all wrapped in one wide-scale choose-your-fate package.

The player ultimately is shouldered with the role of a creator, one burdened with a myriad of choices on how his creation will be.

Do you design your robot for war, or peace?

Do you grant your robot the ability to think for itself/himself/herself, or do you subjugate them under the heel of humanity's whims?

Depending on your choices, the world will be vastly affected.

What I love is the length of in depth detail the creator of this game went in order to make every choice feel like it had weight and significance.

The passage of time is another thing I truthfully enjoyed -- the temporal existence of humanity, but more centered on family. Some of the moments in the game were true tearjerkers!

Overall a very solid 5/5 from a gamer who was initially hesitant in getting into text-based CYOA games. This game has wholeheartedly made me a fan of this style of fiction for life!

So kudos! I would recommend anyone reading this review to pick this game up.

reviewText:
Written after my fifth playthrough.

In interactive novels the writing is (literally) everything. And on that merit alone this one succeeds with flying colours. It's just so well written, I really can't praise author Kevin Gold enough. His real-world technical understanding of the concepts involved make Choice of Robots emminently immersive and believable without going (too far) over your head. And beyond the technical details, this is just good old fashioned great storytelling. Whether you choose to roleplay the asocial genius with only robots for friends, a cuthroat captain of industry, a devoted lover, an artist, a power hungry tyrant, or any other of the myriad life paths Choice of Robots presents, this game will tell you a story that is fundamentally about being human. And it's a compelling one at that.

Every time I sit down to play, I'm choosing to reinvest my precious time in a game that I know is going to make me really feel something, and often it's something completely different from the last playthrough. I feel thrilled when a long term goal comes to fruition, and conversely the way things spiral out of control sometimes can be genuinely upsetting. Whether I achieve my starting goals or not, almost every playthrough prompts me to redefine what it means to win. Because five playthroughs in, I'm still finding myself becoming attached to the small cast of characters in new ways. I can't say that about many other games.

Although the replay value of this game is quite high because of all of that, there is one caveat. I'll call it the Taris Effect (KOTOR players will already know what I mean). The story will always start the same way, and there are only a limited number of ways out. The choices in these first big branches can become familiar, and the immediate results start to lose their impact after only a few plays. In Choice of Robots' defense, the number of smaller and more unique branches quickly multiply once you get off Taris out of school. Not really a dealbreaker I'd say.

Overall, if you're looking to try something new or even if you just liked choose your own adventure stories as a kid, then I highly recommend Choice of Robots.

reviewText:
--A MUST BUY--

I purchaced this title because I've always been a huge fan of text based games. Let me warn you about this novel, IF YOU BUY THIS THEN EVERY OTHER TEXT BASED GAME WILL BE RUINED FOR YOU. Kevin Gold did a fantastic job at really telling a meaningful story. All your choices shape the entire story. I was so impressed in fact that I also purchased this game for my iPhone just so I could continue playing on the go. I've completed the game eight times on my iPhone copy and still there's more I could do. Here's a few of the pros and cons:

PROS:
-Long gripping story that will keep you entertained for hours.
-Choices that actually shape the story around you.
-Many different endings that can change with the smallest choice.
-When you think you have a part of the story figured out and you believe you have the perfect stategy for making the most money the game laughs in your face be changing the outcome of that situation on your next playthrough..

CONS:
-Will make you realize that no other text based game can compare.
-Could use a few more main characters in the story.

All in all, I'd give this game a 9/10, worth every single penny.

reviewText:
At the time of writing this, I've just finished a one time play through.
And I came into this with no real idea what to expect...

I don't really like reading books but this felt like a book to me.
In a nice way because making choices and shaping the story to your wished makes for a truly engaging experience.
The story is so deep, like, really really deep.
You care for the characters, and from my experience, the characters change based on your choices. My best friend turned out to be a manga artist while my friend who also played the game didn't even have said person in her story at all.

I do feel like the story is too short, mainly because I was so invested that I felt empty and sad when it ended.
However, that does not mean it's bad. It's the opposite honestly, it made me, a person that does not really read, wanting more and more until the end.
And seeing as every choice seems to affect the story, it warrants many playthroughs. And replayability only means a good thing. Certainly when you're looking at +-3 hour long interactive story for only 5 euros.

>>>> Please do play this, for your own sake, you're missing out otherwise <<<<

reviewText: What a fantastic piece of futurist literature! I played the more peaceful route but was exposed directly and indirectly to the repercussions of my actions and that of others outside of my control. I was enlightened to the social, political, and economics prospective atmospheres of the future, with a large focus on the effects of introducing artificial intelligence (or lack thereof).  The relationships I developed felt more real" than most other C.Y.O.A. games (the exception being the Heroes Rise Trilogy) and I genuinely felt bad when I pushed friends away for the sake of the growing demand for my robotic knowledge.  My ending felt a tad rushed but it may have been due to my overall decisions having little differentiation from my initial stance on robotics.  All in all
date: the author knows his subject very well and it shows in his writing (largely with robotic ethics and boundaries).  If you are trying to sate an urge to experience an Asimov tale
recommended: craving a 2001: A Space Odyssey journey
hoursPlayed: and/or wanting to discover what the future may hold for robotics from a modernized perspective

reviewText: probably one of the best choose your own adventure game out there would most definetly recommend it

Well designed, engrossing story.  I played three times the first day after purchase, and delighted in the different options.  It elevates itself above the common sort of these games through its free choices and deeply moving themes.

Amazing! I am in awe at how this story affected me, personally. Maybe it was because I named my character my real name and it is a story about a computer scientist [which I aspire to be!], but the way the story played out and how I could see the consequences in my actions almost put me in tears. If you are looking for a 'choose-your-own-story' game this is definatly a great game to consider. One minor flaw would be the fact that there is no save game function - This being the reason my timer (As of writing this) is at 29.3 hours! Other then that *minor* flaw, an absolute amazing story game and at an excellent price! I would definatly reccomend for anyone who would like a game to just be able to read at their leisure and to just generally get into and enjoy playing/reading!\n\nOverall: A steal for the cost if you like reading!

If you're not sure if something like this is something that you'd enjoy; ask yourself, do you enjoy the dialogue sections where you select choices on games like Mass Effect?

If you do, I'm sure you'll be extremely happy with your purchase.

Something that is missing from modern games is not having your actions really affect the storyline, and boiling the game down to just the decisions allows the writers to actually have decisions have real meaning. It makes a nice change of pace from just the superficial choices that a lot of modern games have you make.

I was recommended (and later gifted) Choice of Robots by a friend.  I'm a huge Transformers fan, so a game entirely revolving around the idea of playing a character that creates robots and the impact/influence that has on the world immediately grabbed my attention.  I tried the demo, and was hooked.\n\nI'd never heard of the developer, Choice of Games" before now

reviewText:
I can't remember the last time I read something that draw me in like Choice of Robots did. I just finished playing this, and have to say that this is probably the best thing I paid 5€ for. It took me a lot longer to read through than what other put as the average, 5 hours (I don't think they counted the demo's time) when the average seems to be 2. I guess I just took a lot of time to read and ponder the options. I also played through the night, so my tiredness might have affected the time it took me to read.

There are a lot of options. A lot. And a lot of possible outcomes. I'm gonna replay this at least 3 times.

I recommend this for anybody looking for an immersive and plain good choose your own adventure, or a read, depending on how you look at it.

Probably the best game I've played from, 'Choice of Games'. Now, I've only played four of their games, but I don't know if they could ever top this game. The ideas presented on robotics, humanity, and their future combination has been said before, but the story sucks you in just enough to make every choice seem real. That is if you're actually paying attention to the story at hand. I've played through it several times, and I have to say that my favorite features are in the chooseable beginnings, the shaping of your first robot, and in the dilemma's presented in wanting to make something more human or something completely machine. I don't want to go anymore into it for fear of spoiling something, but I have to say that this is a great buy.
Worth every penny.
Less a game and more a choose your own adventure.  Does that take away from the fun.  Not at all.  A $5 well spent.

Addicting text-only game, i got so hooked that i had to replay it over and  over again.
It's just like a playbook, but has an amazing plot (multiple ones actually), and some excellent, witty writing.

Best money i spent on games!

Definitely recommend this to those people out there that like customization or are fans of the 'choose your own ending' adventure books.

Choice of robots is  more of a novel than a game, but a good one at that. It had me hooked from start to finish as I made my choices throughout the story. Not every decision - by itself - changes the path you're heading down on, but if nothing else the next page of the story takes it into account.

If I were to give this game a score of 1-10 (5 is your average game), would be a of 7. Reason for the score is some pages felt a bit out of space or I would have assumed that scenario improbable based on my previous choices.

If you're a budget player, I'd say go for it. I only had a single play through so far and already got 1£/H value out of this title.  Looking at the list of achievements there is much more to be had.

I've played a few visual novels before, but never something as engaging and thrilling as this.  The story had me glued to the screen, and I sincerly fell in love with the characters and character development.  The choices were wonderful, and things you thought didn't matter came back to take its toll on you later in the story.  It's a game that you can enjoy multiple times- and get vastly different outcomes.  Great work, and I'll keep an eye out for any future products from this company.

Overall well written, engaging, and at times quite touching.

Occasionally, some of the text pieces don't seem to properly reflect past choices. However, I didn't notice these things on my first playthrough, but rather as I started experimenting with all the options and those instances were rare enough to not taint the enjoyable reading experience I had.

Recommended to anyone who likes / thinks they might like text adventures, or those Choose Your Own Adventure books many of us read as kids.
Best interactive novel I've ever tried/read.

Its a strange game where you get out as much as you emotionally invest into it. My first time playing I actually teared up. The next 2 or 3 I enjoyed roleplaying as different personality types. The next 5 times I was mainly trying to play the game as differently as possible to see more outcomes.

It is interesting and smart, it will make you think.

It is very shor but worth a look if you enjoy A.I. related narratives and choose your own advcenture games.

The fact that I shall never truely see my Ariel, is something I may never let myself live down. The perfect companion, the perfect friend. And, while she was not able to answer the question asked in Hamelt, she was able to become as close to a human as I am. Living and experiencing life, despite all of the sadness.

I doubt I will replay this game, simply because this first experience was so powerful for me. But I highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys an excellent story that can bring about the most surprising feelins of satisfaction and an almost parental pride.

Ariel was humanoid, with a wooden body and aetherial gold and silver face. A bit like an angel, though her wings were often overlooked, her kind came to care for humanity, protecting and ensuring their happiness all while maintaining their own sentience.

Choice of Robots (CoR) is possibly the best interactive novel I've ever read.

The description is pretty much self explanatory, but it's so much more.  This is a very well written novel in seven chapters, and while similar things happen during these seven stages, exactly what happens and how it interacts with later chapters is entirely up to you.  When they say the choice (and consequences) are yours, they mean it.

You might not expect much replay out of an interactive novel - certainly I didn't.  Well, I'm currently in my third playthrough.  Again, the core events happen, but exactly how and what comes as a result is entirely up to you.  The endgame for the two complete playthroughs so far were very different.

Do you want to be the 'bad guy' and, as the ad says, try to take over Alaska?  Do you want to try and launch a golden age with robots and humans side by side?  You can do both, or neither.  Each choice you make has the opportunity to lock or unlock certain issues, and how you handle these issues directly affects how your robots turn out.

The writing is top of the line:  The author is obviously well versed in the English language.  After awhile you forget you're playing a game and think you're just reading a novel.

This game... is intriguing. Probably a depiction that the developer would approve of. After plenty of playthoughs, I am still stunned in how many ways you can fundamentally influence the development of the story. It is more than a simple author prefers his story line
date: but you are free to do small deviations"

reviewText: Essentially a choose your own adventure novel but one that, for me at least, overflowed with originality and meaningful choice and consequence. Permanent decisions make each choice irrevocably important. Choice of Robots also manages to tackle the issues of humanity and existentialism (among other common themes of the genre) in a fantastic manner. Choice of Robots is cheap and well worth your time and money. Plus, you'll even learn that a pickle is a viable replacement for a light bulb. What's not to love?

Not much to say really since it's a choose your adventure based around your character and how he goes about making his robot, but my first playthrough and the choices I made gave me an amazing story and one (this coming from someone who does read books, but not often enough) that kept me playing (reading) until it was done. This is probably one of the first games in a while that has actually kept my attention in a VERY long time to keep me playing (reading) the whole way through and in just one session. My first run of this story ran me about 3 hours. Though I imagine you could end up with more or less depending on your choices in the game.\n\nIf you love stories and especially Robots I would say check this out. At its very low price point and willingness to go through a few times to get multiple stories that change drastically based on your choices. You could get a lot of hours of enjoyment for a good price.
Masterpiece.

Choice of robots is  more of a novel than a game, but a good one at that. It had me hooked from start to finish as I made my choices throughout the story. Not every decision - by itself - changes the path you're heading down on, but if nothing else the next page of the story takes it into account.

If I were to give this game a score of 1-10 (5 is your average game), would be a of 7. Reason for the score is some pages felt a bit out of space or I would have assumed that scenario improbable based on my previous choices.

If you're a budget player, I'd say go for it. I only had a single play through so far and already got 1£/H value out of this title.  Looking at the list of achievements there is much more to be had.

reviewText: This is proof that a good narrative and story matters in everything.
This is THE BEST text based adventure game I've ever played. I'm really impressed with the whole thing.

Loved it, it was a great experience. Want to play it again for more endings and such.

The only thing that makes me slightly angry is that the game is basically free to play on their website. While I technically don't have anything against paying for good work of art (which this title is) I feel a bit mislead, simply because I took a dive with my money and found out the game was good rather than read it an appreciate it with some money later.

EDIT: Sorry, I was wrong. Only 2 chapters are available for free, which is a nice way for me to prototype what kind of gameplay I want. Purrrfect.

reviewText:
Choice of Robots is a very emotional game, with a lot diversity of content. Now, there are a few paths that basically lead towards the same directions and the same events that happen no matter of your choices in game. In other words it is the same skeleton, but the skin differs based on your choices.

Now I wish I could say more, but experimenting with different paths is too time consuming as there is no save-game feature. I mean the game saves when you exit, but if you make a mistake, it means you must restart the game. So experimenting with different branches after the initial playthrough is discouraged, due to the tediousness of having to go through the same choices everytime to get to a divergent point that you are interested in.

I have few hours on record due to the fact that I completed the game twice in a relax reading session, but again, the lack of a Back option or of a Save feature, discouraged me, as I do not like tedious activities. As such I couldn't experiment more with it.

I would rate it at a pleasant 8/10, good content, diverse storytelling based on your choices, you actually get to care for your actions. If it had a save feature so I can easily play other divergen paths, I would've rated this 10/10
This game is absolutely fantastic.\n\nNever in my life have I been so emotionally moved by a videogame.

This game is a choose your own adventure book. Do you like those? Do you like books? If not this wont really change your mind, but if you do I recomend this game.\n\nIt has a unique scifi setting set just far enough in the future.
Wow.

Having played through a few times to the end and experiencing a different story each time, I must say I think this is a fantastic game. For anyone old enough to remember adventure book games, Choice of Robots is a must. I would also recommend it to anyone who likes RPGs or who enjoys a great story. Don't be put off by the text only format, there is a lot of replayability.

reviewText: Fascinating game!  Really like the ethical and social considerations of the creator.  If you like a good cerebral, text based game, you'll enjoy Choice of Robots.

This game. Very first time playing saw me attempting to create a robot who could have the whole human experience. I set of on my own without any money with my first creation, Adam, and lived with my girlfriend Elly. Despite trying to stay out of the limelight, I still seemed to find myself in the wake of total wars, robotic-organic relations, etc. After being released from max security prison (long story) for attempting rebellion against the increasingly totalitarian government (longer story), I married Elly, created a second robot named Eve, and moved away to a small house in Alaska. Eve fell in love with me, and as much as I loved seeing my creation display such emotion I couldn't reciprocate. As a result, Eve's life was misery. One day I passed out, and was diagnosed with having a life threatening genetic disorder. Refused treatment and attempted to build my own robotic vessel, dealing with the emotions of my 'family' all the way. Current body finally passed, wife watching over me and firmly holding the hand of the new me. Amazing story, with so much variance. 10/10 Would transcend again.

reviewText:
There isn't enough game here to pay $5. There isn't even enough, if it were on sale for $1.

It's a branching path story game that decides what story to give you based on your alignment of a couple sliders. The choices are obvious as to which alignment they affect (building a metallic robot increases its military, and decreases its grace; giving it wings gives it grace and reduces its military usefulness). But, the story has to keep prompting you to interact with different parts of the decision tree, so you get weird things like being a multi-millionaire and choosing to employ humans in your factories in Detroit, but then you go to war with China, and now you're sorry you ever let the Chinese get near these things. What? When did the Chinese gain the ability to rip off my robots and make them militaristic? Oh, because I used cheap chinese lithium ion batteries? That's ridiculous. If my company is successful, and there's design changes happening, and materials are getting upgraded, let me source better batteries from somewhere else. Don't make me pick a motorcycle battery when my company is supremely profitable.

It's not open to be whatever you want it to be. You're allowed to type only on fields that don't matter: your name, your robot's name, your robots pronouns. You can't affect the story, you can affect the flavor text. If you choose one of the built in options you will rarely have a tie in back to the originator (Isaac Asimov names are one of the built in options, so you can get references back to those books in later dialogue if you themed correctly). But if you manually type in a name, Suddenly the game has nothing pithy to say about how your name and your situation relate back to the book.

It's not a very visually delighting game. Black text on a white background. Only one button is styled. The Next button. All other buttons are your OS' default look and feel. It's lazy design, and it hurts that it's not free.

The author chose to point out on every page of the UI that he is a Ph.D. which bears out my experience with most Ph.D.s. More concerned that everyone knows you spent a lot of time in school, than putting that knowledge to work. Good job on your Ph.D. now do work that isn't already bested by a group of people posting on free Choose Your Own Adventure forums.

reviewText: No save, no undo, no plans to fix. The descriptions aren't always clear. Based on the descriptions, I might make one choice, and the game decide I've made the complete opposite choice. Since this breaks the story, I can't keep going. Since there's no save or undo, I can't take a step back. So I have to go back to the beginning and choose all the same exact steps to keep playing.

reviewText: Tl;dr: Choose-your-own-adventure science fiction novel with choices that are affected by your previous actions. Awesome.\n\nWow. I just finished one possible playthrough, such an amazing game. If you love science fiction that makes you think, or game by tell-tale where actions have consequences, or even the old choose-your-own-adventure novels that were so great, pick this game up. This is entirely text-based, but don't let that put you off. It puts you in a world that could never be achieved via graphics or programming, where the world is your oyster. You may not realize the ramifications of your actions till much later, but that is what makes it so great.

reviewText: I am still in my first playthrough and I am enamoured in how enveloping the story is. I used my own name for the character, so naturally I began to make choices that I feel I would need to make, and even though I wanted a military-oriented plot line, I found I was progressing upon a path that I could not truly predict.\n\nThere is one thing that I feel the need to be critcal about. The relationship concept! gay or straight, this person or that. It seems so two-dimensional when confronted with such a refreshing take on science-fiction. I would simply advise the author to do some research into polyamory, as it can be likened to an evolution of human interaction, let alone human/robotic interactions!
