reviewText: Very engaging thus far.\n\nNo music, no pictures, just text. A Choose Your Own Adventure" game apparently. You are a robotic engineer in Sillicon Valley building a robotic companion and shaping the world along the way over the course of your life. Each section of text comes with you making a decision potentially altering your path - what you are doing with your life
date: how the people around you will react and what will happen with the world as a whole (or not
recommended: as being passive is usually an option too).\n\nThere are several values regarding your life and the character of your robotic companion that you'll influence with your choices through the entire game and which will affect the choices you can make later on decisively. For example you can build a humanoid-looking robot and teach him (or her
voteText: or whatever - you are given freedom in naming and adressing things) to get along with people increasing his "Empathy" and "Grace" values or
votesHelpful: shape him to clearly stand apart from humans and handle guns and stuff increasing "Military" and "Autonomy". This value-play can sometimes feel a bit like a guessing game
votesTotal: and how it will affect your later course is hardly predictable
votesFunny: which can be seen as a good or bad thing I guess
commentsCount: but then I suppose that's just how life works too.\n\nPerhaps at times the game feels a little bit too much like a dating simulator or relationship juggling. Maybe this comes natural with such games and with them trying to resemble life and how choices affect it. I can't say I remember having played anything like this before ("Cinders" maybe)
column16: so I don't know. Still: There is a "Romance: ..." placeholder at all times and the game doesn't hesitate to question your inner self quickly whether you have romantic feelings towards a just recently introduced character of either gender
column17: or make them burst out with acts or words of affection towards you right away
column18: which felt a bit unrealistic and forced or at the very least awkward to me at times.\n\nSometimes events are pressed on too quickly for my taste. There are some happenings and characters I would love to see elaborated more
column19: but the game can be unforgiving there
column20: making you lose track of them rather quickly pressing onward towards new things and situations. Even some greater time leaps of multiple years it doesn't hesitate to do where a little more patience might have served better. I haven't finished the game yet though so I don't want to fully judge that yet. I don't claim to know better in terms of writing. Perhaps I'm wrong and it's just right
column21: elaborating more could end up losing track of things and aims and such and bloat things up artificially. I just sometimes felt sad and unhappy about the turn of events and how I lost touch to some characters or screwed up in geopolitical questions with no chances of undoing my mistakes. But I guess I can try better in additional playthroughs

reviewText: By far the best Choice Of game. It's incredibly thoughtful, well-written, and has choices that don't feel forced at all. reviewText:
Fought Anubis, the God of the Dead, and won. 10/10

Seriously, though, this is an awesome story, which you need to experience. I've already completed this game twice and am still itching for more. Also, if you're a fan of Isaac Asimov, like myself, this is definitely something you'd enjoy.

While I've yet to see everything this has to offer, it does seem a little short, at times. Though, this is more a problem with interactive fiction being spread over multiple arcs, rather than this game, in particular. Still, with 300,000 odd words, you'll get at least several hours of an immersive and engaging story, which is well worth the price.

reviewText: I'm a sucker for good interactive fiction and this fits the bill - even if it is more of a CYOA. This was a wonderful story with solid (but not spectacular) writing which provoked a bit of introspection and a deep attachment to the characters, all of it assited by the number of choices you can make and the consequences that result from them. It has shades of Photopia, Alter Ego and Galatea, all great games. I wholeheartedly recommend this game, although I wasn't a fan of Choice of the Deathless - but Robots has given me an idea to go look through the other stories they have on offer!\n\nedit: 29/12 - and, on another playthrough, I just found out that the game directly references Photopia, Alter Ego and Galatea! Amazing!

reviewText:
This is an unusual novel for me in a way that I connected with it so deeply.... Below is my own story that I wrote through this choose your own adventure novel... I warn you it may spoil the story for you though.



When I play any game or visual novel or anything set within the same timespan as my RL family then I try to include those in the game if it is feasible... if not then I normally find a reason why they are not in the story and build my character and personality around that... in this world my Fiance is dead.

Losing her was not the hardest battle I'd ever though... no that was to come, I felt alone in this world and I had nothing to live for anymore... my days were spent alone and miserable and one of my old proffesors saw this I think and offered me a contract job at his place dsigning War Machines... I'm not sure what led me to create Eden but I think personally it was just longing for a friend to hold my hand when I needed it.

I built her in my spare time and tried to teach her right from wrong... all I wanted was a new form of life.. humans but humans that were well? nicer, my Fiance died because of the system and I was hellbent on making a robot that was not only my friend but looked as beautiful as she did and respected the planet we live on.

I had no idea my work would influence the coming war with china so fluid, my designs stolen for a peaceful loving robot made in her image changed to just want to kill and dstroy... Eden died during this war and I think that changed me somehow.. in the end nothing mattered... all I wanted was my Fiance and that was who I was going to have...

My episodes are getting worse and I can't remember quite what happened now but upon learning I was going to die I had to have done something.. no matter what happens in life one must accept death for what it is... it is life.. without it your not living you just exist.. I'm going now but at least I'll get to see her again... and Eden.

reviewText: Bottom line, strong recommendation if you're a fan of science fiction novels.\n\nThis game is, quite literally, interactive fiction - and very good fiction at that. Gameplay elements are minimal: You're given a choice, possibly your robots' stats changes depending on your choice, then the story continues. The focus is clearly on the (very good!) writing.  But, and this important, your choices actually matter. And that's not a buzzword for once. It's not Mass Effect-style choose the colour of the light beams in the ending" sense
date: I mean that choices matter in that you get completely different stories depending on your choices. A run takes about 30 minutes
recommended: depending on how quick a reader you are
hoursPlayed: but there are so many different branches (both minor and major) that you can easily sink hours just into exploring."

reviewText:
At first I was skeptical about buying a visual novel for $5 but the review rating pushed me to try it. OUTSTANDING! I highly would recomend this to neraly anyone. The writing was quality, story was great! I really felt as though my choices mattered and lead me to a unique crafted story. 5 outta 5

Below is the summary of my entire first game which took me 4 hours. The entire thing is a giant spoiler if you have not played yet! But I figured I'd post it for those of you who have :)

Summary of Completed Chapters

Chapter 1

On the day you first built Ariel, you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make Ariel more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a wooden winged robot with a humanlike head and humanoid hands.

Then you went back to your place to teach Ariel some words.

Chapter 2

The next day, you hooked up Ariel's biodiesel engine and demoed for Elly. You then took Ariel to see Josh, who was impressed and agreed to fund your education if you would work for him after you graduated. Josh told you that evening about how he'd once been a juvenile delinquent, essentially, but turned around because he was inspired by Asmiov's book I, Robot to make a robot company called U.S. Robots."

As months passed
date: you became busy teaching Ariel about the world through the Internet and taking her to the park. Your funding from U.S. Robots kept you in Professor Ziegler's good graces during this time.\n\nIn time
hoursPlayed: a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle
voteText:
heard about Ariel and asked for an interview. You agreed.

Chapter 3

You gave Mark an interview
helpfulPercent: and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview Ariel.\n\nMark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and Ariel. When Professor Ziegler found out about the article
votesHelpful: he was very displeased
votesTotal: and finally kicked you out of his lab.\n\nMark's article also attracted the attention of one "robotObsession1987
votesFunny:
known in real life as Silas Cooper. When you met up over coffee, he told you that he used to do classified robotics work for a government lab, but left because he couldn't tell what nefarious purpose the technology would be used for.

Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved at his funeral to be remembered not only for your intellect, but for your kindness as well.

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist.

Chapter 4

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. But they were unimpressed with Ariel. You couldn't find any other interested companies, either, and you eventually went bankrupt. Unemployment seemed to be common in the United States, and it seemed people tended to blame either robots or China. Riding on both of these sentiments, Jacqueline Irons won the presidency. After President Irons enacted a series of protectionist tariffs to keep out Chinese robots, Sino-American relations steadily worsened.

The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter.

Chapter 5

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. But you refused.

Silas was worried that he was being targeted by the government's anti-spy measures, and asked you to help him. But you weren't very helpful.

An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy. Elly was captured and incarcerated as a result.

You found out through Mark that Juliet died while performing field tests of Ariel V, Professor Ziegler's copy of your robot.

In the end, America muddled its way through the war relatively unscathed. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot.

Chapter 6B

You created a humanoid companion robot named Galatea, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed Galatea was interested romantically in you. When Ariel and Galatea were attacked in the street, Galatea accidentally killed someone. Galatea was forced to spend time in jail, but suffered no permanent consequences.

In a last-minute attempt to find a life partner, you proposed to Galatea. And, what do you know -- it worked!

Chapter 7

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to surprise your mother with a gift for the holidays. You learned it was your surgical technology that had kept her alive this long. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death.

You chose to replace the malfunctioning part of your brain with an artificial neural network. You survived the surgery, thanks to your own robot surgical technology. You celebrated a birthday party with Ariel 2, Ariel's artificial child, and looked forward to celebrating many more.

reviewText:
High quality writing and an abundance of choices that influence how the story plays out. Even choices that don't seem to be all that important can alter the outcome quite a bit.

You should bring the patience to read large amounts of text - obviously - but it's well worth it. The writing is really good and offers not only a nice technical perspective on AI and robotics but also some philosophical insights about life and humanity.

Parts of the story are based on logical extrapolation of current political relationships and events, which makes those parts seem a real possibility for the future and not just some lazy fantasy.

Everyone who is interested in AI and robotics and is not afraid of reading should buy this. Everyone else should at least take a look at the demo before simply skipping this game altogether.

reviewText: I've always had a soft spot for text adventures.  This is a good one.  It's got more in common with a Twine or Inkle story than Zork, but that works really well for the narrative.  Think of it as a choose your own adventure game with stats and value-based options.  And yes, its a lot better than that sounds.  I've only played through the story once, but it was a good one and there are plenty more paths for me to explore.\n\nMy only criticism is the lack of a save feature.  It took me a little under three hours to play through once, though that was with the occasional break.  Expect to spend about two at a time on this one.

reviewText:
Short version
Another excellent text-based choose your adventure game from Choice of Games. Even after the sale is over, you should still buy it and give it a shot.


Long version
I love robots and transhuman themes. Worse, I cannot resist a good story. I was definitely going into this primed to enjoy it, and enjoy it I did. I truly do not wish to spoil the story for anyone, mostly because the fun of this game is in going through it, making one set of decision and then looking back and saying oh but I wonder what would happen if I had..." then going back and seeing what would have happened. I will say this: stick with your decisions. At least for the first run. There are some benefits to things most of us gamer types would call "failure" which take the story in interesting directions.

Do not go in expecting "Robot Tycoon" or a Visual Novel. This is neither of those. It is a choose your own adventure novel from the 90s
date: rebuilt with 21st century technology. Choice of Games have made the genre better
voteText: and easier to recommend. Buy it now. And if you will excuse me

reviewText: This game is great. Picked it up on a whim, and had the most fun playing a game I've had in a very, very long time. The story is exceedingly well written, and the complexity of the story trees allows for genuine immersion. There were few times where I felt forced to choose from options that felt unnatural for my character, where I expected there to be many more. Players may find, as I did, that there isn't much replay value. Despite the volume of choices allowing for many directions a player could take the story in, it's unlikely that any one player is going to find all of them equally appealing or interesting. I tried replaying it and found I had to make choices I didn't like in order to have a different story than the first time I played through. But given how inexpensive this game is, and how much of a pleasure it was to play through once, I really don't think it's a major drawback. I'll pay 3 bucks for a good book I'll only read once. If you would too, definitely get this game!

reviewText:
This is my favourite of the 'Choice of Games' games I've played, while it's much shorter than most of the others it has a lot of variety and the story changes dramatically based on your choices.

Get involved with the war against China or stay out of it completely, its possible to stop the war from even happening in the first place!

Build a robot for war, or for love, (heck one option that you can get is to build sexbots!) legalise human-robot marriage, you can even have a cult around your robot.

Conquer the world and rule it as a dictator, or have your robots infiltrate society and get humans to accept them as their rulers.

While there are some glitches in some of the choices (like building your factory in China has no negatives in the war against China) this is by far one of the best text-based game I've ever played.

reviewText:
I was really excited to try this game out, so I grabbed it while it was on sale. If I could give it a neutral rating rather than a negative, I would.

I didn't get too far into it before I had to stop. The writing, for lack of a better phrase, tries too hard. It's written like a fan-fiction, with oddly specific details that detract from otherwise good writing. For example, at one point you get a phone call and have to pick if it's the CEO of a startup calling you or if it's your manga artist friend. The point at which I decided to stop was when a hip young reporter ordered a PBR. There's just so many things that feel unnaturally forced into the story.

I think it has a lot of potential, but it's a little rough around the edges for now.

reviewText: It's difficult to attach yourself to an experience like this. Most I imagine would rather pick the most cathartic route and run with it. but even as your decisions veer up and down the scale, The story always retains its organic cohesion and compelling storyline. While one or two characters can be a tad two dimensional, every decision you make affects the story in wildly branching ways. for something this simple, little more than a flash text algorithm, I was left on the brink of tears in my first playthrough,  Not only do your decisions resonate, but they provide a good series of compelling arguments about the nature of artificial intelligence. This isn't a game. Nor is it a novel. It's a narrative experience that evolves beyond its initial choose-your-own-adventrure" If you have any interest in sci fi
date: but worry that the lack of graphics might turn you off
recommended: I still recommend you give it a try. you might find it more engaging than you expect."

reviewText: If I had to sum up Choice of Robots in a single word, that would would be 'shallow', or perhaps more accurately 'dilluted'.\n\nIn a game where one of the selling points is it's expansive word count, Choice of Robots rarely delves deeply into any of it's topical material before whisking you off at a break-neck pace to touch briefly upon the next item in what feels like a laundry-list of tropes dealing with robotic life as explored more deeply and, frankly, better, by numerous classical science fiction novels. Choice of Robots' chief sin is that it gives too many choices (and often times, the results of thus feel rather arbitrary) and as a result is unable to delve deeply into any particular aspect in which it ham-fistedly attempts to explore. All in all, this game is entirely skippable, despite it's low price-tag.

reviewText:
My robot Judo chopped a bulldog...twice.

Try not to cry.

Cry alot...twice.

10/10

I really love this topic (especially A.I and anything related to it), and I wasn't disappointed with this unique kind of game. Your choices does have an affect, Telltale should learn one or two things from CoR.\n\nI've got one ending so far, and I think this was the best one you can get from the game. Now, I have to go, figuring out if  I'm right. 10/10

If you've enjoyed other games from Choice of Games I would you try this one out as well. It has a similar setup to them in the fact that you play through the story making choices, those choices affect what sort of person your character is by increasing certain 'stats.' Throughout the story you'll have a choice to make, but some of them may be grayed out because of the previous choices you made had increased or decreased certain stats to a point where your character wouldn't be likely to make those grayed out choices.

I've been enjoying the game up to this part where there was a set of choices and one of them just didn't quite seem to fit. Fortunately, and unfortunately if you happened to choose that one the story does flow from there, and what the characters say seem to make sense, yet that one choice really needed to be reworked.

So I finished the game, and I felt a little disappointed about the ending. It just seemed a little flat. This game is about choices, and yet the (one) ending (I reached) I felt didn't relay to me how my choices changed the world around me.
Helped both sides in the war, then took over Alaska and bombed my previous S.O. along with the city.\n11/10, would destroy the world again.

An amazing and multi-faceted story (stories). Its Azimov+Twain+Gerrold. And more.\nEverything starting from design, to how the names (and backgrounds) of the surrounding characters change according to your choice is breathtaking.\nThe Best of all games published with the help of choiceofgames.com so far.

For these Choice of Games CYOAs, which I tend to find pretty limited over many playthroughs, Choice of Robots has a lot of choices and a great deal of different ways that your game can end up.

First, a note of warning, you cannot save AT ALL. It's one go every time and if you die, you're gone.

I don't feel like putting out a long review, as there are many that get the job done better than I will, but I will say this:

If you want a game that will make you think some over ethical and personal ramifications of an alternate future, buy this game.
Very good game, good writing, lots of choices.
One of the best Choice games

This game is absolutley amazing!
I played a lot o visual novels in my life, but this is simply the best! When I play, I m reliving the story, the decisions I make are the same I would make in real life, never before i have felt so connected to a game character.
This game is really worth a lot more than it costs and it proves that our imagination and a good story is stil the best game engine on the market.
The only thing that, in my opinion, is missing is the music, I would really appreciate some good cyberpunk music to it.

In summary, if you like real-life RPG games and you like robots, this game is a must-have!
I will buy any DLC and sequels without a second thought!

I will admit my partiallity to games of this kind prior to lodging the review;
Robots are my favourite trochee!

Witness a compelling story as your actions will influence the character of your robot, as well as their ability to 'have character', and the only loosely formuleic and entirely unpredictable actions of your robots influence your humanity. The story the game generated for me was easily comprable with a good speculative sci-fi novella, however downsides included a shortage of character development (possibly triggered however by my character's insatiable bloodlust).

All in all, my robot, 'Killall', loosely followed the common 'robot struggle for autonomy and recognition' formula, but there was a lot in the way of robot parenting that could be performed by the player to divert the robot's agenda, wherein the interaction between player and robot (second player character, I felt) was not a chore at all, but felt the part as the most real interaction in the game.

If you're a reasonably fast reader like me (no worries if your not), this game is four hours of constant engagement in reading, again equivalent to reading a novella. For the price tag given, you can seldom expect so much out of a game.
This is an amazing CYOA novel that truly lets you choose your own adventure. This game gave me serious feel.

Choice of Robots is the classic Choose Your Own Adventure format text adventure you remember from your childhood taken to the next level. The amount of choice you have through the game is staggering with every little decision impacting the story.\n\nYou play as the inventor of the world's first self learning, sentient, robot. You are about to shake the foundations of society and change the world forever. What that change turns out of be is entirely up to you. But, just because you have a goal in mind, doesn't mean you or your robot will be cut out to acheive it. If you load it up on philosophical data and have it play with kids in the playground, don't expect it to perform the way to expect if you want it to conquer the world.

Just incredible... an experience that you must read. Don't buy the game expecting an action game, buy it expecting to think  about the story and even question yourself Did I choose right?" "Should I... or...?". Decisions matter
date: at the start they seem easy but they will affect the whole gameplay later
recommended: as you keep reading the decisions are harder
hoursPlayed: you don't even know what's right or wrong since nothing seems right or wrong anymore.\n\nBest buy I did in a long time. You can play it over and over and you will get different outcomes."

reviewText: Can't believe how many times I played through this game (and most probably will play more). Only reading text, choosing options and clicking next. If you have an interest in science fiction or more particulary in robotics and AI, this is an incredibly interesting experience.

I love this game and was the first test adventure based game and I grew attached to the characters (most notably the robots.) I've played through the game three times one where I made a non comabtive robot, the second where it was for war (by far the bleakest outcome) and the 3rd where I died to Tammy and i'm considering to go through a few more time making diffrent choices to see the outcome.

IMPORTANT!!!

Before you buy this game keep in mind this is nothing but reading so if you hate reading then you will not enjoy this game.

Overall i give this an 8/10 not the best story written but with choices that matter and characters that have diffrent personalities and your robot evoles with you make it hours of fun and  full of replayability if you can spare the $5 and love a good story pick this up!
Tryed the demo and had to see the rest of my" story
Despite being a completely text-based game, I found this to be more enthralling than so many other games I had played beforehand. This is an incredible $5, and I recommend you buy it.

This is a text-based game around robots. Your actions and decisions throughout the game will have an immense impact on the further development of the story. A story with so many choices, endings and comical pearls - once dramatic, once romantic and once militaristic. Which path will you take? Needless to say, this means there is a lot of replayability value. I'm currently at my third playthrough and I'm enjoying every single minute of it. Absolutely recommended.

reviewText: The best game ever played! :D 10/10 if ur thinking of buying the game u should! I was happy when i finish the story :D

This is one of the greatest text based games i have ever played. Choice of Robots makes you consider the possible consequences of all of your actions; make your robots so advanced that they rebel or make them unconditionally follow the orders of humans? The choice is yours.

A really well made and fun text game, I actually enjoyed it and it kept me at the edge of my seat. The writing is a little bit cheesy/blunt but what the hell, it's a game.

+ interesting story
+ nice variations
+ every decision matters; has consequences, both obvious and surprising
+ nicely strung together (I made a pretty strange robot, but the story nicely accomodated for it)
- writing style is a little too 'vanilla', but that's purely objective on my part.

9/10

SPOILERS

I became a war profiteer by making hyper-intelligent warbots with a strong sense of morality for the military which conquered China. And eventually the robots realized just how flawed humans are, they revolted and I got executed.

TL;DR Much awesome, robots, a must play for people who like choices and reading.

When I started playing this, I thought it would be a quick jaunt through some basic choices. I turned out to be an engaging and well spun tale complete with tough decisions and moral choices. Each time your playthrough the game it offers you a new path to follow and a new direction for the story to go. It was the little things for me like naming my personal robots, my company, and even my own child that really made it memorable and more interactive and immersive. Overall, it was well written, engaging, and definitely replayable. Also, it's packed with achievements if hunting them down is your thing.

I would recommend this to anyone who has a love of science fiction, choices, reading, or clicking boxes!
I've been thoroughly enjoying this game. It's well written and offers a variety of choices. If anyone is looking for a solid romp with an robot companion, this is exactly what you need!
I really enjoy playing this game.  It reminds me of the old choose your own adventure" novels
date: except with a more philosophical bent and an rpg element.  The choices you make have an impact on society
recommended: as well as your own personal relationships.  You grow to love your robot(s)
hoursPlayed: who learn and grow and change with every decision you make. You agonize over choices that could have far-ranging and profound effect.  I'll definitely play all the "choice of" games that come out.  I give this one five stars."

reviewText: Choice of Robots may seem like a boring text based game but I can promise you that it is not as simple as that. Many games nowadays, claim that your in-game decisions affect the outcome and thats mostly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. In the case of this game however, it is definately true that your choices affect the outcome. I highly recommend this game.

Truly amazing, I thoroughly enjoyed this game so much i wrote this (http://thesteampunkpiratefromspace.tumblr.com/post/109995229449/a-choice-of-robots
(What happened in my story, well, Mr Ghoulds.)
There are no words to describe what i felt when faced with some decisions...
Thank you.
A great story with a ton of charm. Well written, and with many, many different paths. So far, the best Choice of Games offering, and sure to be very hard to beat.

This game is absolutley amazing!
I played a lot o visual novels in my life, but this is simply the best! When I play, I m reliving the story, the decisions I make are the same I would make in real life, never before i have felt so connected to a game character.
This game is really worth a lot more than it costs and it proves that our imagination and a good story is stil the best game engine on the market.
The only thing that, in my opinion, is missing is the music, I would really appreciate some good cyberpunk music to it.

In summary, if you like real-life RPG games and you like robots, this game is a must-have!
I will buy any DLC and sequels without a second thought!

I will admit my partiallity to games of this kind prior to lodging the review;
Robots are my favourite trochee!

Witness a compelling story as your actions will influence the character of your robot, as well as their ability to 'have character', and the only loosely formuleic and entirely unpredictable actions of your robots influence your humanity. The story the game generated for me was easily comprable with a good speculative sci-fi novella, however downsides included a shortage of character development (possibly triggered however by my character's insatiable bloodlust).

All in all, my robot, 'Killall', loosely followed the common 'robot struggle for autonomy and recognition' formula, but there was a lot in the way of robot parenting that could be performed by the player to divert the robot's agenda, wherein the interaction between player and robot (second player character, I felt) was not a chore at all, but felt the part as the most real interaction in the game.

If you're a reasonably fast reader like me (no worries if your not), this game is four hours of constant engagement in reading, again equivalent to reading a novella. For the price tag given, you can seldom expect so much out of a game.
This is an amazing CYOA novel that truly lets you choose your own adventure. This game gave me serious feel.
This was freakin awsome. i cant wait to play the few other games like this i know about. just awsome

Choice of Robots shows that text-based CYOA games can be fun and addicting. In CoR, your choices define the story; there is no illusion of choice. Your choices have impact and they will make a difference. As such, CoR is definitely worth two or more playthroughs because you'll get vastly different situations and events each time.

The choices you get are interesting and thought-provoking enough that it's almost always guaranteed you'll find one you like. Oftentimes, they are just downright tough. However, CoR is very forgiving in that if you do happen to make a less-than optimal decision, you can just continue right on because the resulting consequences are just as interesting. I would not recommend you to restart the game because that is unnecessary. You'll also get many backdoor options that you can fall back on if you choose to.

For your first playthrough, you shouldn't be paying too much attention to the stats. And don't try to guess what the author wants or what the right" answer is
date: because this is your story. Just sit back and enjoy the ride by making choices as you see fit."

reviewText: A very interesting game.  Not the kind i've played before but i was looking for something different. Played it through three times just to see some different endings, and discovered not only the possible endings change, but also the middle and late game story as well.  My first play through i chose to be as good" as possible and found the ending very suitting.  Then i tried for something a bit more militaristic  for my second play through and was decidely unhappy with the ending (though it was true to the choices i made).  My last play through was As Myself
date: and strangely enough the ending was similar to the first play through but with some noticable differences that seemed to reflect in game alot of my real life situation (like being broke lol) Im sure there is alot of game content left to explore if im willing to make some different choices
recommended: but im content to leave it be.  In real life we cant walk down every road we encounter
hoursPlayed: and must content ourselfs with the choices we have made.  All and all i find that this is an excellent short game at just the right price and highly recomend it to anyone who wants to try something different."

reviewText: One of the best things i have ever read. I would highly recommend this to any one, and every one that is literate.
I didn't think text adventures would still work in this day and age, but Choice of Robots proved me wrong. I love the game and recommend it whole-heartedly to everyone who likes reading and gaming.
Best game to simulate hard working in office.

I've had sad endings, and I've had happy endings. I grasped at eternal life, and even watched it drain away from between my fingers. I did my best to rule, and I did my best to love. With all things considered it made me question my mortallity and wish even more in real life for singularity. For life unending. I wish this dream to be true, life with out the risk of death. for we gasp at the great unknown and all hope that we carry on some how, where some simply respect that functionallity just ends, that we just shut down. I do not want to accept this, and I wish that I never experience death. To say that it terrifies me is an understatement. I want to see mankind's journy to the stars, I want to witness our first contact with intelegent life outside of our world. But in a way I don't want to just copy my memories, I wish to experience indefinitely, I know that with time I would forget the past, memories so dear to me fading away... but hopefully in the same respects I would make new memories, and hopefully people I hold dear and close join me as simply intellectual, and then perhaps oneday in physical bodies again.\n\nIt's just that I simply don't want to say goodbye, this world is so beautiful, and we have only scratched the surface of what's outside of our own world. I wish to see it all, but I don't want to be trapped. I want to be free, alive, experiencing, feeling, loving, for as long as the stars flicky in the nights sky.
Worth every penny

Spoilers!

Theres no pictures, no audio sound, but this a very moving chose your own adventure story. Using your mind to create the never ending wounder.

My first play though, lead me to create my own company making Medical A.I., got sued, then a nation stole my design, bankrupting me.

Even a close friend had to flee the country, All along the way my A.l. robot, Ally was a fateful companion, and in many ways my child.

If your looking for a good story were you have a real part in how it's shaped you said pick up this game. Skip that 5 dollar Mcdonalds run just this once, I did.

WOW! If the subject of AI, the singularity, or the blurring of the line between man and machine has ever interested you, I PROMISE this interactive novel will suck you in and not let go until you live out all 30 years of your life that this story covers. AMAZING!

I just put $5 into this knowing nothing about it. I play through an entire story and would play again. One of the best stories I have ever read ever. Can't wait to see what is next from this company.

An interactive story that blows Telltale out of the water.

10/10
It's very great, could last me for many, many, many, many hours to days.

Fun, quick, reading-based game. It's like a choose your own adventure on steroids. Obviously if you don't like to read, you won't like it.

Good interactive story with fun sci-fi references.

It has quite a few ways to play through and many paths to explore.

A fantastic game with huge replay value. Keep in mind however that the game doesn't take it's self realy serious all the time, bearing that in mind it's only as joking as you want it too be. Every choice leads to a diverse set of circumstances that grows wider the farther into the story you get. At the start your a grad studant finishing what amounts to the first truly working robot ai that sets the standard if you let it. You get to choose the peices that make up it's form from a wide variety of parts, and then you shape how the robot grows. It can be anything from mindless killing machine to a companion equal to any human, to a god like entity that shapes the course of history, or you can end use it to further your own ambitions. Your personal life impacts your work and how your robot grows. The comedy is fantastic and ocasionaly if you want it, fourth wall breaking.  Please take the time if your a sci-fi buff to buy this game.

My first playthrough was an interesting experience. It was also beautiful, immersive, and unfolded in a way I can live happily with. The story writing itself is very well done, and often times very touching depending on what path you take.  Sure there is no 2d or 3d world for you to explore, but in a way this gives you much more in the form of imagination. It provokes you think about things that other games could never offer to you as the player.\n\n10/10 For this game. Sincearly, one of the best games around. I've been buying the wrong games for a long time, I think I know what I will buy more of.
Very pleased with this purchase. Played through 4 times with different results every time. 4 plays is about all for me- now it is repetitive. Overall: well worth purchasing and playing a few times.

I want to start out saying that i think this is a wonderful game.
Only negative is that the main screen was a little bright, but that is very minor.
This was a game that had me really stop and think about what i wanted to create.
I knew I did not want to make a War like robot, and one time i used him to try and save someone i loved and it ended with us being hurt because of the path i picked.  I Came to really like the few main characters i stayed with and i really liked my first robot and how i could see Him" or "rhe" develop as i thought to my self what i would teach if i had a robot to teach.
Great game and i am looking forward to more!
The game really makes you feel connected with the characters.
I would have gladly spent more than the $5.00 for this game."

This has got to be the most varied CoG game I have bought. With branching choices that leads you to alternating paths way off from previous choices and fun 4th wall jokes.\nWell recommended for people who like to read :P (obviously)\n

Game about robots. It is your decision what you and you robots will become. Will they start a rebelion and you will lead them to create better place or you will create utopian cities and live with your loved-one.\n10/10 - whould conqer Alaska again

I was in love with this by the time I finished making my character, and robot. Short, but with high replay value (steam says 5 hours, over about a dozen plays), the plot bends to your decisions in most places, making it well worth going back and playing again to the world unfold differently in response to different kinds of robots.
I was hesitant for the first few clicks... and then hooked. Very poignant. You really do feel like you're leaving your mark on this world.

A screencap of some of the text from this game caught my eye on a friend's twitter, so I decided to pick it up. I didn't really expect to enjoy it so thoroughly though. A great story that can take many different twists and turns.

Tons of lifes. Tons of endings. I really enjoyed this game, and I hardly find games I enjoy these days - Even fewer text-based games!\nI usually hate text-based games, but this was by far the best one I have even played. It's cheap, so give it a go!

I've always had a soft spot for choice of games, they mix my love of reading with gaming and have huge replayability.  As far as this particular game goes, i like how it adds a bit of flavor on later playthroughs by breaking the 4th wall through hints.

I laughed, I cried, I loved my little robot to death. This game put me through something that I cant even explain. This game, although unconventional in its gameplay is easliy my game of the year, this late into the season.

Definitely for people who are more into c.y.o.a. games and books. I'm finding it very enjoyable and, surprisingly, it's been really easy to create a new protagonist in my head with each replay (despite there being a limited number of choices and repeated events and scenarios).\n\nWorth checking out if you're into robots and storytelling!

For a simple text-based game/interactive novel, Choice of Robots is very likeable with many possible branches. Starting with a strange dream leading to the creation of your robot, you can end up anywhere from building robots capable of love and marrying one yourself to leading a revolution against humans with your robot army/comrades.

My only two wishes are being able to save and reload to certain points, though it might ruin the experience - and being able to change certain aspects of my robots design later on or having more than one model. (e.g. placing a gun on my Robot to appease Ziegler then after graduating remove it to keep my robot elegant).

(It says I haven't played it much, but that's because I did so offline...)
Bought this game because of course I did. Played this game because of course I did. Dead on the inside because of course I am. 10/10 would cry again

This game is wonderfully written, and has surprisingly good replay value.  The plot wasn't easily predictable, and it's wonderful how your choices end up altering not just your personal robot, but the very course of human history.

Also, I made a drone with a hyper-realistic human face that grinned when angry or upset, and had extremely sensetive, lifelike human hands.

10/10 would creep again.

What is Choice of Robots? Choice of Robots its a CYOA, or Choose your own adventure, game. It is a well ridden path full of amazing stories but this one by far is my favorite. This one stole my heart on the first playthrough where I tried the more empithatic approach, messed up horribly, and fell in love. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes to make their own decisions and magnificently written stories. Rate? :10/10
One of the best peices of IF that i've seen in a long time.

Absolutley amazing. I never got into choose you own adventure books, but this was awesome. So many different ways your story could go. If only done one story, and i couldn't stop.\n\nOverall everything is 14/10

More of a choose your own storybook with some flag elements and stats thrown in, a somewhat unique bit of media worth its cost at least. It has some blemishes no doubt, but is otherwise thoughtful and choices feel meaningful where relevant. If you like philosophy or role playing games, worth its cost and enjoyable. If you need to bash somebody to bits or shoot something up, probably a bad call.

Very different from other games out there. Felt like i was reading old school G.I.Joe books!

good replayability too!

10/10

Amazing game. I named my Robot Tyrael the angel in the sky turned moral. Main goal: To protect humanitarian ideology.
Made her out of wood, she got shot in the head by an FBI agent and I prevented a robotic uprising.

A fantastic game that througly rewards you based how much you are willing to be immersed by it.
Play it through, build up your stats and leave behind a legacy that will challenge the future.

Choice of Robots is the classic Choose Your Own Adventure format text adventure you remember from your childhood taken to the next level. The amount of choice you have through the game is staggering with every little decision impacting the story.\n\nYou play as the inventor of the world's first self learning, sentient, robot. You are about to shake the foundations of society and change the world forever. What that change turns out of be is entirely up to you. But, just because you have a goal in mind, doesn't mean you or your robot will be cut out to acheive it. If you load it up on philosophical data and have it play with kids in the playground, don't expect it to perform the way to expect if you want it to conquer the world.

Just incredible... an experience that you must read. Don't buy the game expecting an action game, buy it expecting to think  about the story and even question yourself Did I choose right?" "Should I... or...?". Decisions matter
date: at the start they seem easy but they will affect the whole gameplay later
recommended: as you keep reading the decisions are harder
hoursPlayed: you don't even know what's right or wrong since nothing seems right or wrong anymore.\n\nBest buy I did in a long time. You can play it over and over and you will get different outcomes."

reviewText:
This is a text-based game around robots. Your actions and decisions throughout the game will have an immense impact on the further development of the story. A story with so many choices, endings and comical pearls - once dramatic, once romantic and once militaristic. Which path will you take? Needless to say, this means there is a lot of replayability value. I'm currently at my third playthrough and I'm enjoying every single minute of it. Absolutely recommended.

reviewText:
As a gamer who usually plays games with fancy graphics, I didn't quite expect myself to try out a game like this. I had several games from several different categories, and i never thought of playing an interactive novel before. During the holiday season, i noticed this game, oddly titled Choice of robots, but it was really cheap, and had good reviews, so i picked it up. Maybe it was my nostalgia towards books, or maybe my curiosity for something different, but i did find myself pleasantly surprised by this text based adventure. It touched my heart in a way no other game has done before, and made me learn something about myself, even things i didn't even think would in me. It showed me flaws in myself, and generally actually did make me a better person.

I highly reccomend this game, as it seems like it has a bit for everyone, and it has the potential to really learn about our true selves.

10/10, amazing story
This was such a awesome game, thanks to the level of detail that the author(s) put into it.\n\nAlways found myself causing a utopia after nearly ending the world... several times.
Awesome game, lots of choices. Very few (choices) feel out of your hands.
simply amazing.

This was my first text based game and CYOA and I wasn't quite sure what to expect. After a few play throughs I can say I am impressed and am thoroughly enjoying Choice of Robots. Do you want to be the destroyer of worlds? lover of your creations? savior of the world? Or hated by all?\n\nI would like to say there are a couple of typos that i've noticed. The game also seems almost to basic with no real save functionality. Something I would like them to add along with a back button. But in its current state I give it a 8.5/10 and was a great value when I bought it ($3)
If you like making choices (:p) in games or if you like reading, or if you are human you will love this game.\n
I never review games, but this one is amazing and deserves attention!

Truly amazing, I thoroughly enjoyed this game so much i wrote this (http://thesteampunkpiratefromspace.tumblr.com/post/109995229449/a-choice-of-robots

There are no words to describe what i felt when faced with some decisions...
Thank you.
A great story with a ton of charm. Well written, and with many, many different paths. So far, the best Choice of Games offering, and sure to be very hard to beat.

Very easy Read, fun and engaging story ,despite the fact that I normaly Eat books, I never thought I would like making  my own story...  for my first interactive book, and the effort and Fun way it was portrayed I give this A.    10/10  would buy more!!!!\n

this game has so many interesting things that can change based on the choices you make!! the replay value is amazing, and the story is way immersive. i definitely recommend it. its quite possibly the best 'choice of' game thats been published, and that's saying something.

only flaw is that you cant give yourself a robot horse body toward the end? wtf

made me crai :'(

reviewText:
This game is amazing!!!
My first play was in the demo just to, you know, try it, and I got so immersed in it, I had to get the full game.
When I've finished I was stuned and full of emotions and thoughts, even without graphics or soundtrack It's beautiful, the narrative is great and the characters are charismatic enought to make you like them, I don't even need to say that the robot is the most charismatic, I loved my robot Ariel, I couldn't even try to dislike her.

I really liked this game!!!

This game is thoughtful, beautiful and imensely entertaining. It's smart and funny, packed with puns and refferences.

Every nuance in every choice you make will have wonderfull and terrible consequences, and after you finish the game once with the choices you think seem reasonable yourself, you can play the game at least 10 times more and experience 10 completely different and interesting stories, and it will be worth it (just make choices based on different values, you will be surprized at what is possible in this game).

This is the best 5 bucks i spent on a video game in a long time. If you ever thought reading was boring, get this game, and think again.

I have a lot to talk about this game, but I'll try and make it as short as possible. This game may be one of the most brilliant I have ever played. The storyline is amazingly well-crafted, with so many differant possibilities made after every choice! The main characters you meet all have very wonderful and colorful personalities that you will either enjoy, or clash over in the game. However, as it's obvious from the screenshots and such, this is a text adventure game. So if you want the full enjoyment, yes. You will have to read. A lot. But if that dosen't keep you from hitting that buy, then do it now. For only a 5$ game as of now, it is definitely worth the price if you just don't mind reading it. This game definitely has my stamp of aproval, no matter how little the stamp of aproval is for some random person on the internet. So once more, if you don't mind it's text-heavy gameplay, buy this game immediately. You'll get your money's worth.
A bit short but it was entertaining while it lasted

Every decision is a struggle :))) Can there be a save point please?\n\nThis game makes me question my humanity. Apparently I'm very bad at attending to my husband's needs, but I seem to make my robots happy :))
A true CYOA. Your choices actually do matter, two people's playthroughs will be very different. This isn't a matter of choose one skill and stick with it" which so many do
date: even the others by the same developer. There is no real fail state either
recommended:
even failing all your tasks will still give you a very interesting story to read due to the rather superb writing.


With that being said
hoursPlayed: it is very short. 3 hours or so will be all you need to finish it. Some people may find the price too steep for such a short experience. However I did get two playthroughs out of it
voteText:
which may be worth considering.


This is the only game I could truly recomend by Choice of Games. Oh

This game is incredibly charming and well written, especially if you enjoy reading or writing Sci-Fi stories. I just finished Asamov's 'Robot Visions' so this game is right up my alley. Even if you dislike Sci-Fi, the plethora of directions that stories can take based on your decisions adds an entertaining and fresh mechanic with a good amount of replayability. If you've ever had the patience to pick up a book for recreational purposes, you'll be able to appreciate this fantastic interactive experience.\n\nGet this game! It's well worth the low price.
Absolutely, insanely good.  I've gone through the book 8 times and have not had the same story.  A great throwback to the choose your own adventure books.

reviewText: One playthough is not enough to write a proper review, but I'm not much of a reader. I've seen this guys work on the web, and this is a true testament to the author's efforts. This is what Choose Your Own Adventure always hoped it could be.

If you want a sci-fi text based adventure game, then Choice of Robots is for you.

Like seriously, this game is amazing. Granted, the writing can be a bit clunky at times, the concept is solid and the branches the stories can break into are very different from each other.

The fact that it was inclusive of different genders and sexualities was also a plus and gave the game more depth than some other adventure games. The stats were a welcome addition as well.

Formatting is easy to read due to the high contrast between the letters and the background and the font is big enough to read comfortably.

This title is enjoyable.

It's pretty cool worth the money and a good library builder. In terms of visuals and UI it is sorely lacking but is a great game because of the multilinear story line. I married the female President, became a billionaire and beat China in one. The other I China took over the world and I died and the last playthrough resulted in a robot rebellion led my robot attempting control humaity and invade Mexico, I think?
Im reading this to my daughter, she loves it,, it is a great book but with mer we read it over twice... old but great\n

If you enjoyed choose your own adventure styled books you'll really enjoy a lot of the Choice of Games products. Sometimes it's nice to just read and use your imagination rather than have amazing graphics. Choice of Robots had me on hte edge of my seat, which I completed for the first time the very night I started reading. Characters and story are well written, now I just need to go create a real life robot and I'll be set!

A nice story that has many, many distinct playthroughs and can end in various ways. And it's only 5€.

reviewText: I've never written a review of a game on Steam before having never particularly cared one way or the other despite enjoying most games. But I have a soft spot for interactive fiction and this is a fun, touching example of the genre. Admittedly not the most complex (see works by Graham Nelson, Emily Short, Andrew Plotkin, and others on http://www.ifarchive.org/) but the feeling of being a contemporaneous Susan Calvin is one-of-a-kind and evoked lazy afternoons reading Asimov and Bradbury.\n\nI couldn't recommend this more if you're looking for good interactive (science) fiction on Steam.

Spoilers!

Theres no pictures, no audio sound, but this a very moving chose your own adventure story. Using your mind to create the never ending wounder.

My first play though, lead me to create my own company making Medical A.I., got sued, then a nation stole my design, bankrupting me.

Even a close friend had to flee the country, All along the way my A.l. robot, Ally was a fateful companion, and in many ways my child.

If your looking for a good story were you have a real part in how it's shaped you said pick up this game. Skip that 5 dollar Mcdonalds run just this once, I did.

Choice of Robots is, at its core, a choose your own adventure book - and a well written one, at that. The stories available to the player are interesting and, most importantly, immersive - I got carried away in several playthroughs as events occurred and I was swept up not in how I should react according to the choices provided, but how I would react myself. When any story - book or movie or videogame - gets me invested to that point, I can give it a full recommendation.\n\nThe only thing I particularly have grief with is the lack of a save system, which makes replays arbitrarily longer, especially considering how the first chapter is largely stats-building with fewer (relatively) plot-influencing choices. If you want to retry a choice to see how it turns out - or worse, misclick at any point - the only recourse is to restart the entire game. While there are arguably reasons that justify this limitation, I personally dislike them, as it makes end-game content much more difficult to explore due to the exponential increase in time commitment.

Choice of Robots is a CYOA game where you create robots and make decisions that will effect both your life and your robot's life.

During my first playthrough (skip to avoid spoilers) after creating my robot (Airu) I got kicked out of school for not conforming to a military agenda. I met up with an old friend who I started to date. Made my own company. Indirectly started a war when my company's security got hacked. Refused to use my robots to fight in said war. Got Married. Got thrown in prison where I stayed until the president got me out. Made companion robots possible. First companion robot was madly in love with me and made my spouse jealous. Reassured spouse and then together stood up for equality between humans and robots. Decided to have a kid. Mom made me tearful. Had medical problems. Companion robot made me want to cry. My spouse made me cry. Airu made me cry more. Underwent surgery and became slightly robotic. Airu created a kid for herself. Companion robot and Airu started to like each other. Changed a lot and I survived.

I really enjoyed the story and writing of this game and will definitely be playing more of it.
One thing I thought was cool is that you have different romance options available to suit your preferences, and that your other choices seem pretty varied so far. The only downside is if you don't like reading this isn't the game for you and there is no sound but this is a solid choice for just $5.

reviewText:
I didn't expect that very first choice to have the impact it did, but it did.

I've been fond of CoG's listing of interactive novels ever since I found the Heroes Rise set, which was a wonderful three parter. Then it was Mecha Ace, and now Choice of Robots.

You affect the world, you affect everything around you with the choices you make. Is your robot going to be a soulless military machine? An emotional believer in robot-human rights? Or something else in between? Will you hate all the humans and assume they're exploiting you, or work with one or two and see where the road takes you?

It's a long road, and there are so many ways for it to end.

I'll say it straight: this isn't necessarily a game that most people would enjoy; it has no visuals and, while in general is short, is a long read for someone who isn't willing to sit still and stay focused for approximately an hour for one play through.

However, for someone who is looking for a good story, Choice of Robots is worth the money you spend on it and is a wonderful narrative. I blog about stuff like this all the time, and am always looking for a good read. Choice of Robots was far better than I could have imagined and was worth every penny, as well as will be worth all the time it will take in order to get each and every achievement.

The story is interesting on it's own; make a robot, decide who to work for if anyone, go through a war, maybe even find love. The choices you're able to make through the game is really what puts the cherry on top of this game; the game's mechanics follow a normal choice based game, but the choices you choose are relevant throughout the story; depending on what you choose at the beginning alters the ending(which is where some choose your own story games lack, and instead, your choice is more relevant between different sections of the story). It's interesting to choose what you would like to do and see all the concequences this leads to.

I won't spoil any of the actual game because it's so worth it to check out the whole thing, but I highly recommend this game. As I said, it was short; for a fast reader like myself, it took a little over one half hour to go through one ending of the game, but it's very touching and you fall in love with the characters you meet/create.
Weird as hell, and not written all that well, but still very interesting.

This game makes me a little bitter that i dont actually have my own robot, game addicted son named Eric and a robot husband named Alexander who ruined my marriage. At least I can go and see what happens if i want to take over alaska. Come on Eric, it's time for murder!\n25/10

Meet Steve, a blocky, cube-headed little robot. Taught to love, not fight. He is quirky, cute, and oh so loveable, and I've never even seen him. And meet Olive, my companion bot. She shows a little more complex emotion than Steve, but is just as likeable. Olive wanted to love me, but I wouldn't allow it. I was married, and although I accept robot marriage and robot-human romance, I was not up for it myself. She felt rejected. Steve was clueless, like a happy, yet genius, child. Though Olive was hurting, with her advanced emotions coming into play. One day, we were just taking a walk together, Olive and I. She asks what she can do with her life. I say she must look after Steve, as I am dying. She didn't want that, so I ask what she wanted to do. That's when she replied Whatever I want
date: and then ran off without another word. That was the last I'd seen of Olive, after her murder trial, after all her learning and experiences with me, Steve, and my wife. Her and Steve, my creations. My children.

reviewText:
Having played all the Choice of Games, this is definitely the best one. If you can stand a text based game, just buy it, play it, and play it four or five more times.

While parts of it aren't the greatest storytelling and some of branches are fairly ridiculous (intentionally or otherwise) it is written intelligently, which is novel for something that deals in sci-fi.

Yes, parts of AI or embelished or simplified, but overall it's a story with surprisingly thoughtful elements, a good range of control over what happens, decent writing, and not horribly short like some (though not that long - it is after all the limitation of choice your own adventures with actual branching naratives).
It is just brilliant! Amazing piece of work. It gives you opportunity to live the story the way you like.\n10/10
Very interesting, I've only gotten through a few chapters, but I'm already unable to stop reading. :)

It like a normal RPG almost like a cheesy one, however since its texted based it uses your imagination, this can be a good thing or a bad thing, because it if your brain is a turd then you probably won't enjoy this. However for about $5 this is quite a nice read.

First playthrough, I got ripped off by the Chinese, who then invaded America, destroying my life in the process. I got angry and tried to fight my robot and he killed me.

Second playthrough, I got my arm blown off my a psychopath and then died in my car while trying to murder her.

I f***ing love this game.

10/10

After playing a few runs of this interactive story all in one sitting I can say I highly recommend it. It is well written and there are so many options that change the story. Definitely worth looking into if you enjoy reading.

This is one of the best that the choice of games series has to offer. Other games allow you to take different perspectives on things but take you through the same events nevertheless. Choice of robots however actually has world-changing choices and brings in some true feels and thought-provoking questions.\n\nMy only complaint was that I wish it was longer.
It's the first game that made me want to write a review. It's a really good read, and the choices feels relevant and interesting. I am very happy I played this game.

I have played a few of these Choice games, including Champion of The Gods and Choice of the Deathless. Choice of Robots is by far the best one of the lot. Detail. Reactivity. Replayability. Maturity. Heart. Robots is superior to every other interactive novel out there in every way, and I don't feel that is an exaggeration.\n\nIn Choice of Robots, you make a robot. Surprise. You determine its appearance, materials, power source, and ultimately influence its personality (though not entirely). As you guide your young" robot through the strange customs and idiosynchrasies of modern human life

reviewText: A fun little choose-your-own adventure game that will sufficiently entertain you for about an hour. After that, you'd have to replay and make different choices, which I don't like to do. Possibly too short to justify the 5$, but whatever, I liked it.
Gonna cry now.

Oh wow that was a shock.

First time playing a CYOA game. Got married to a robot girl, had a robot daughter, happy ending

Emotional rollercoaster, that much is true.

Considering the replay value, 5 bucks is worth it. Get some good music in the background and play through it a few time. Worth every penny.

Holy hell. This was a lot heavier, narrative-wise, than I thought it would be. Damn. Do you like science fiction novels? Do you like games that let you make your own decisions? then you'll love this. It's been a long time since I looked at a choose your own adventure, and this was damn good.

I suppose the only thing I'd like is a back button, or an option to enable a back button, mostly because sometimes you can misread the text or confuse the intention of the words. Also, the summary you receive at the end saying what you did was a little confusing in some parts, it said things I didn't think I'd chosen.

I feel super conflicted about some of the choices, but I'm guessing that was the intent? Anyway, this was a fun hour and a half. Definitely worth it.

For what it is, this is a great game. Killbot and I  shared a special moment watching the sunset, right after assassinating a few key threats and conquering the Chinese. Two peas in a pod, we were. inseparable. Before I died I transferred all my memories and conscious thoughts into an android designed to look just like me. Jbonez and Killbot 4eva.

Loved this game.
It's very remniscent of the choose your own adventure books some might remember from their youths. But it's more than that, the adventure seems to be able to take multiple, very different twists and turns. I've just completed my second play through and other than presence of a robot, the story couldn't have been more different.
I picked this up very cheaply in a sale, for much less then the cost of a pint of lager. It would have been well worth it, even if I'd paid full price. I'm unlikely to still be playing this game in a month or even a week. But it's provided a full nights entertainment for me at a meagre cost and I may yet play it through once more, at the least.
I'll certainly be looking out for more of this companies games on steam in the future.

When I saw this game in the store, I wondered if the game was really as good as the reviews make it up to be. And I can easily say that it is. The story of the game is immensly deep and interesting, and it still manages to give you the power to really choose your own path. I'm not going to say anything about the story here, but If you find robots and artifical intelligence interesting, you will love this.\n\nIt took me more than 2 hours to reach the end once. However, from what I have seen so far, the story changes dramatically as you make choices, and you could play this again and again many times to see all the interesting plots it has to offer.

Choice of Robots Is, to me, the coolest thing ive ever done. The first time i tried it was on my brother's tablet (Also keep in mind this is the first choose your own adventure game ive played). I played through twice, the Military route and then the Empathetic route. The story each time differed so much and it just made me want to play more, so i decided to but it on steam. Alot of games advertise their great graphics, but what looks better than what your brain imagines?\n\nWhen i eat chicken, usualy i think the skin is the best part. thats usualy due to the meat not being good enough. CHoice of Robots, is like a chicken thats so freakin good that i dont even need the skin. The meat" of this game is the best part! They already strip away the "skin"! This game didnt need graphics or sfx
date: jsut the story telling and content is amazing.\n\nA few bad things: Though this game can change alot depending on your choices
recommended: i feel like i wanted and expected a few more choices. ITs probably just me wanting a more of this game

reviewText:
What can I say about this amazing story? It made me think, and interact on a level I haven't recieved by any game based on a first run without many discussions. I even named the robots I created after 2 human characters in Futurama (well one's a mutant). It was definately different, I was thrown curve balls all the time. I even had to deal with ♥♥♥♥ing Sarrah Palin, who practically caused WWIII with China (Not the neighbor she can see from here back yard, but China). You can even read my results of the whole story in this review if you'd like. Next run I do, I hope to die immediately. Have fun.


Chapter 1

On the day you first built F.R.Y., you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make F.R.Y. more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a metal bipedal robot with a masked head and humanoid hands.

Then you went back to your place to teach F.R.Y. some words.

Chapter 2

The next day, you hooked up F.R.Y.'s biodiesel engine and demoed for Elly. You then spent the afternoon perfecting F.R.Y.'s motor control and parts.

As months passed, you became busy teaching F.R.Y. about the world through movies and taking it to the park.

One day, however, Professor Ziegler claimed that F.R.Y. was not appealing enough to the military, and demanded you change it. You refused, and Professor Ziegler kicked you out of his lab.

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about F.R.Y. and asked for an interview. You agreed.

Chapter 3

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview F.R.Y..

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and F.R.Y..

Mark's article attracted the attention of one robotObsession1987
date:
known in real life as Tammy Cooper.

Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved at his funeral to be remembered not only for your intellect, but for your kindness as well.

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist.

Chapter 4

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. They were happy with the state of your technology, and gave you a contract that allowed you to purchase a factory. That allowed you to build a robot factory in Alaska. You decided to use your own robots for your workforce, but leave humans in supervisory roles. When you finally shipped robots to Galen Medical, they were pleased with the robots you delivered.

Your business suffered a blow when Chinese companies, aided by Chinese government hackers, began to steal your technology. Your business was dealt a further blow when there was an explosion at your factory, caused by a bomb set by Tammy.

You were visited by a politician, Jacqueline Irons, who asked for a campaign donation. Despite your unhelpfulness, Irons won the presidency. The newly elected President enacted a series of protectionist bills that ultimately made China angry, and they cut off the U.S. supply of rare earths.

The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter.

Chapter 5

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. You agreed, but specified that you only wanted to provide robots that were nonviolent in nature. But when your robots held a protest, you decided it wasn't worth it, and you backed out.

But you soon realized that you were not happy working for the government and quit.

An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy.

You found out through Mark that Juliet died while performing field tests of F.R.Y. V, Professor Ziegler's copy of your robot.

In the end, America lost the war, and the Chinese took over Alaska. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot.

Chapter 6B

You created a humanoid companion robot named LEELA, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed LEELA was interested romantically in you. When F.R.Y. and LEELA were attacked in the street, LEELA accidentally killed Tammy. LEELA was forced to spend time in jail, but suffered no permanent consequences.

Chapter 7

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to handle your mother's estate, since she had passed away recently. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death.

You chose to undergo surgery to remove the damaged tissue in your brain. You survived the surgery, thanks to your own robot surgical technology. You celebrated a birthday party with Dusa, F.R.Y.'s artificial child, and looked forward to celebrating many more.

reviewText: I love it. I miss these games so much.

I created my robots to imitate life and to be as human as possible a decision that was both bad and good depending on your outlook.\n\nThis game gives you so many choices and the choices i made i actually cared about and sat in my chair analyzing each one for several minutes. This game makes your imagination run wild and gives you the options to create whatever story you want to. I highly recommend this game to any lover of choose your own adventure books or robots.  This is a must buy!
A gem; Kevin Gold - you gold spinner, bringing back genres and forcing imagination...what were you thinking offering all this time spent for such a low price?  You dirty dog you, you nailed it.

Overall, I enjoyed this game. Some parts of the story/script felt a little childish, but for the most part it felt like a smart and connecting experience. I would even go so far as to say that, at times, it pushed me to question aspects of my own life. Thought-provoking, involving, and sometimes even emotional... I think this is a trip anyone will enjoy taking.

Choice of Robots is an interactive novel adventure absolutely brimming with imagination. I LOVE THIS GAME.  It's innovative, creative, enthralling, and outright fantastic. I very much suggest you try it.

This game didn't really seem like mt sort of game, but a few of my friends had it so i thought it might be good. All i can say is even if you dont like the look of this game you should get it, it is really well done and (so far) it has not got boring in any places, I highly recomend this game!

I must say, first I was unsure if a entirely text based game / novel would be worth the money.
After playing it for some time and trying different options, exploring the alternatives, I must say that I thoroughly enjoy this Novel.

The writing is great, the story is thought through so that the story after your actions (the choices you pick) always is plausible and in tune with the character you decide to play as. The different choices really make the story change significantly and doesn't end in the same spot as after one of the other choices, so you will often discover something new as you make your way through the novel.

Granted the lack of anything gamelike"
hoursPlayed: only plain text and checkboxes. Can be a hurdle to decide if you want to spend your cash on it
voteText: but for me the story is fully worth getting this engaging and well written novel.\n\n[Better than Mass Effect

I thoroughly enjoyed this game and so far have played through 3 different times to achieve different aims.  It is a little confusing at first to know how your choices affect the gameplay, but you get the hang of it.  I will be checking out the other titles from Choice of Games that are rated high for more choices and nonlinear storylines!
