11/9
Mr. Robot was a real ♥♥♥♥♥ who loved to love and learn.
Loved every minute of it, with extremely high replay value.

This is my first review on Steam, and I must say that I'm extremely impressed by this game. The level of details and sophistication is over the top. The consequences of your choices are never dull and always exciting and full of emotions. I just love this game and the maker for this experience.

Pros:
+ The story itself is not linear but very open to your choices so that you can have freedom to decide your own fate in this game.
+ The maker knows what he's talking about about various topics including robotics, artificial intelligence, computer science, and even legal aspects of human rights.
+ The characters are very unique and personal. They are never the same people but are unique in their views and beliefs.
+ The robots you create respond to you according to your decisions.
+ The political aspect of war and moral dilemma was superbly done. I had to pause the game for a moment to decide which choice would be 'right' for me.
+ As a player, you can be emotionally attached to your robot and it feels as though she(or he) is really alive.
+ I just finished the game but I've only unlocked 14 percent of the achievements. There's definitely replayability for this game.
+ Personally, it is far better than your typically 'wifu' games that have shallow stories and charcters. This game allows you to interact with your robots on deeper level.

Cons:
- I really can't think of any. I hope the game would have been longer, but I'm not really complaining.
- No graphics or sound effects, BUT I actually prefer it that way because it forces you to use your imagination. And come on, this game was made by ONE person if I'm not mistaken. I'm still very impressed by the fact that one person was able to write this lengthy scenario of a game.
- More 'war' scenarios with China or other countries would have been nicer.

Bottom Line:
This is an extraordinary game and the maker of this game is brilliant.
Your robots can be as fun and interesting as you make them to be.
It all depends on your choice.
But you might not like this game if you believe that graphics and action are a must in a game.
Personally, I appreciate deep story and memorable characters (I'm also a fan of FF games).
So you'll like it (or love it like I do) if you are like me.

PS: Oh and I'm also a huge fan of robots and sci-fi movies. So, this game was just a delight for a person like me.

This game is thoughtful, beautiful and imensely entertaining. It's smart and funny, packed with puns and refferences.

Every nuance in every choice you make will have wonderfull and terrible consequences, and after you finish the game once with the choices you think seem reasonable yourself, you can play the game at least 10 times more and experience 10 completely different and interesting stories, and it will be worth it (just make choices based on different values, you will be surprized at what is possible in this game).

This is the best 5 bucks i spent on a video game in a long time. If you ever thought reading was boring, get this game, and think again.

I have a lot to talk about this game, but I'll try and make it as short as possible. This game may be one of the most brilliant I have ever played. The storyline is amazingly well-crafted, with so many differant possibilities made after every choice! The main characters you meet all have very wonderful and colorful personalities that you will either enjoy, or clash over in the game. However, as it's obvious from the screenshots and such, this is a text adventure game. So if you want the full enjoyment, yes. You will have to read. A lot. But if that dosen't keep you from hitting that buy, then do it now. For only a 5$ game as of now, it is definitely worth the price if you just don't mind reading it. This game definitely has my stamp of aproval, no matter how little the stamp of aproval is for some random person on the internet. So once more, if you don't mind it's text-heavy gameplay, buy this game immediately. You'll get your money's worth.
A bit short but it was entertaining while it lasted

Paperback, hardcover, or digital - plain ol' books get boring. Choice of Robots is the very thing that got me excited about reading again (and drawing, too!). I started the game with Doppler, meant to be a forever-companion I can teach and live through life with, and we went through a whole decade of crazy adventures (a number of which actually *almost* turned him him a war-machine!)... We even gained a bit of fame as technological pioneers and changed the world regarding how robots lived among humans. This is the first Choose-Your-Own-Adventure sort of game I have ever tried and I... LOVED. IT. To put things short and without any spoilers, if you like to write and read, have a vivid imagination, and love the idea that your choices drive your character as well as the characters in your immediate social circle... then, try this game. First time around, clocking in at 10 hours, I had a score of 115 out of 1000 points possible (with only 8 achievements gained); obviously it has a high 'replay' value. Going to be taking this for a spin again and do attempt #2 to make my perfect, robotic forever-companion... wish me luck! Perhaps you'll succeed in that feat before I do!
this is art. there is no other way to put it.

Started out to make a robot that was loving. Then proceeded to make it more militaristic accidentally. Robots rebel and call me supreme overlord. We then take alaska as a new home for my robots. In my last days I decided to make a robot body for myself to keep my dream alive.\n\n10/10 Will love elly in my next life.

I am not even kidding when I say this, in this generation of gaming, text based adventure games are not that common or even good however, this has ended up being one of my favorite games of all time. Every choice I made mattered. Every outcome because of my choice would at sometimes put me on edge. Another thing about this game is that it really got me caring for the characters in the story and being able to be part of it as well and creating something (robot) was amazing. If anyone enjoys sci-fi films or games or even stories for that matter, try this game out. You will not regret it and the replay value is incredibly high.

I have played a bunch of the Choice of Games and even against the Hero Rise trilogy, the only one of their's that was popular enough to become a series, Choice of Robots is still a great story and game for me to play. There is no other way to explain it other than it is immensly satisfying and even empowering to be creating a robot, and then to be raising it into whatever you wish. Most of the characters are likeable, it is just real enough that you can easily put yourself into your character's shoes and it is a must have for anyone who loved transformers, or just robots in general as a kid, it is a story that captured a sense of wonder in me that no other game had. If I did have any complaints (SPOILER ALERT)  it would only be minor things like how your romances can sometimes feel very rushed. If I could ask for something more it would be more ways to customize your robot (obviously) and a picture of your robot as you keep adding on to it. I realize that this is a novel but in some cases it is kinda hard to fully grasp the descriptions of your robot.

As a long time fan of Choice of Games, this has to be in my opinion their best work to date. The amount of choice pales in comparison to the emotion you'll experience while playing this game - I was actually feeling things - at one point I almost cried. This is a brilliant work that manages to push the view that video games can be art.
Choice matter, and it killed me.
Awesome game - didn't know I had not left a review.\n\nBuy it. Do it. Do it JUST DO IT!

I consider myself very much a fan of robots. I cannot possibly express my love for this game in mere words; an honest expression of my feelings would have to be more like a high-pitched squeal. I have been trying for ten minutes now to come up with something to say, but I cannot. I desperately wish I had a sentient robot companion of my very own.

What can i say about this game that explains it better than amazing. It is a book that you can controll in so many
ways. There are sad endings and moments, and there are happy endings and moments. You could be a crude leader,
or a generous and loving person. This story can have so many different things, i replayed it a few times before i wrote
this review. It was worth the 5$ i spent on it, and i suggest you do the same.
Very pleased with this purchase. Played through 4 times with different results every time. 4 plays is about all for me- now it is repetitive. Overall: well worth purchasing and playing a few times.

I Came to really like the few main characters i stayed with and i really liked my first robot and how i could see Him" or "rhe" develop as i thought to my self what i would teach if i had a robot to teach.
Great game and i am looking forward to more!
The game really makes you feel connected with the characters.
I would have gladly spent more than the $5.00 for this game."

Okay, a text based CYOA set in a (still) possible near future involving robots. If I say more on the contents then that will be a spoiler, so I'll refrain from doing so.\n\nWhat I can and will tell you though is that unlike other CYOA's of similar design this one is very... call it expansive. You really do feel like you areable to explore different branching storylines rather than ye standard three ending routes that many others seem plagued by. The sci-fi bits are extrapolated from current tech, so they are credible enough. Be aware though that it still manages to get bat-guano crazy here and there, but at the time of writing the review I'd say that if you want to try a good CYOA, this is the cream of the crop on Steam.

Everything you do affects your robot, and to witness his/her/its evolution is truly glorious.\nIt’s a standalone game, with plenty of replayability, that does not outstay its welcome. Definitely a Must-have for all CYOA fans.

reviewText: I really enjoyed this and will run through it again at least once or twice. Great value for the cost.
This is super fun! At first, I didn't think I would be able to get into this--because it was text-based--but oh man was i wrong! The story for this is absoluelty beautiful. High replay value.
I understood that my work would eventually strip me of my humanity in the toughing story. What I didn't know is that I would lose my humanity for real.. I couldn't stop playing until the end...

It's a nice change to see a great text based RPG on steam. Delve into the world of a mad scientist creating the first intelligent robot. A choose your own story game with vast amounts of replayability and hidden gems. Will you be good or evil? Smart or crude? Democratic or Fascist? This world is yours to create.
Wouldn't really recommend unless you're a friend of text based adventures. So many choices but It's obvious which one leads to a good or bad ending, there's nothing really surprising here.

Well written Interactive Novel about AI and more specifically the ethics involved in its creation. I have only played through one possible scenario so far but I plan to dive right back in and explore the other paths. I found the story to be so enthralling I was not able to stop playing until I reached the conclusion. I am actually glad there are no illustrations to accompany the story. It allows the reader/player to use their own imagination. I highly recommend this game.

It would be difficult to ask more from this game. I can think of a couple of things, but the number of choices, consequences, depth and adventure is amazing for a textual game!

The form based interface/gameplay is much more easy to use than having to type in commands.

Also, it makes it's convenient to play on touch devices. In fact, the only thing that I find a shame is that we can't play light Steam cloud based games remotely on android or iPhone. Because the 'Choice of' are best enjoyable to me when read / played on the go, on a portable device.
It's not who I am

This deserves a longer review.  I meant to play Choice of Robots for 20 minutes to see what it was like and played it for nearly 5 hours on my first run through.   I cried so hard and I lived a lifetime of mistakes and joy and so much more.  I never knew that text only games, a genre of games that I thought had died in the 1980's, could come back 30 years after their time to hit me so hard in the gut.   This is like the time I thought pixelated graphics had died in the 1990's and then I played Papers,  Please for less than 90 minutes only to realize that a game with even the simplest graphics could still have the power to stare into your soul and reveal truths about yourself even you didn't want to admit about yourself or never even knew about yourself.  Games like Choice of Robots and Papers, Please are the kinds of games that prove beyond any shred of a doubt that video games can be the highest of high art and can have asgreat or an even greater emotional impact on you than books, music, TV, and movies, and other art.  I will be playing this game for a long time and I will be gifting multiple copies to many friends in the immediate future and for a long time to come.
I love this game

I'd give it a good 8/10. The story is long and there are lots of choices that can and will effect everything you do. Unfortunately, I found myself being stopped when making choices that revolved around a more humane choice(keeping human workers instead of replacing with robots, refusing to make emotionless fighters, etc.) which caused my character's company to fail. Which then made me restart the game. But, I apprciated the fact that my choices constantly mattered.
Perhaps it's the fact that I'm not that quite interested in futuristic robots even though I'm a huge sci-fi fan, but I really didn't feel connected to the characters besides the robot that you first create, I did not want to build emotionless weapons for armies, etc.
In fact, a lot of the characters feel one-dimensional. You get a robot companion who, even though you build it so that it should only reciprocate platonic feelings, still falls in love with you, regardless of the fact that your character is married. There are other examples of one-dimensional characters, but that robot stuck out to me the most.
That being said, if you love the other stories/games from this company, like sci-fi and robots, then you should definitely play it.

Highly recommended for fans of text based adventures, visual novels, and good stories.

Choice of Robots; a short story in which you can decide the protagonist's (and thus the surrounding setting's) actions to some extent. The story can be anything, depending on your choices, from inspiring to frantic and to emotional, just to give a few examples. The characters have more depth in them than the player would first think; you just need to get to know the characters to reveal other aspects of personality in them. Oh, and the bots, they're the best.\n\nPersonally I like this game very much. I would recommend it to anyone who likes reading (sci-fi - or fantasy, too).

reviewText: I love text games, its a lost art. And Choice of Robots brings some art, some real storytelling back to it. You make choices here, lots of them, and its not always obvious which ones you should make, its got adult sort of morally ambiguous events as you follow the life arc of the protaganist, guiding or misguiding his or her decisions. Its got /some/ replay value, but you basically try and make better choices than the last play through. Still, for the work and the good plot line, I have to reccomend this.

At the time of writing this, I have only completed one playthrough. One could say that, yes, this review is a bit premature. And I would agree, to an extent. Still, let me just say that it is...

BLOODY AMAZING! 8D

I knew from the very start that I wanted to end up in a relationship with a robot. There were some definite missteps along the way, but I did eventually achieve it. I literally squealed with happiness when I got that to happen.

And I cannot wait to play it again. There are over 70 achievements, due to the variety of outcomes resulting from your choices. If you like a game that is story-driven, where 'choices matter', and you enjoying reading/are a reader, then this is a game for you. Be aware that there are no graphics whatsoever; it's just words in a plain white GUI with multiple choice options popping up constantly for you to decide the direction of the story. If you already are one who enjoys reading, you will most likely come in with a reader's practiced imagination and this will not deter you in the slightest.

GET IT GET IT GET IT!

Edit: At the time of this edit, I've probably done about 6 or 7 playthroughs, and had a blast each time.

reviewText: A fun little choose-your-own adventure game that will sufficiently entertain you for about an hour. After that, you'd have to replay and make different choices, which I don't like to do. Possibly too short to justify the 5$, but whatever, I liked it.

I certainly do recommend this game to anyone who wishes to experience the heavy weight of responsibility and attachment while never truly being able to know what is right or wrong. This is a game that is to be experienced, not just played, and to experience this game is to have your heartstrings pulled and morals questioned. Every choice you make will influence the story permanently, accompanied by an outcome one cannot always foresee. (Sounds a lot like real life, no?) Choice of Robots is a text-based work of art that will make you feel, and is sure to leave you wondering just how much you are willing to risk and sacrifice to protect what or who you hold dear most.

Robots, moral decisions that impact gameplay, more robots, and nerdy humor wrapped into one shiny package? It's like this game was made for me!

Seriously, don't let the text-based interface scare you away. This game clearly has had a lot of thought put into it, and is just the right level of challenging. Even after 13 hours of gameplay I still haven't followed all the paths, discovered all the secrets, or achieved all my goals. How do I fulfill the Robot Statue of Liberty's cryptic orders? How do I make a robot that is capable of love but has the autonomy to live its own life? How do I conquer Alaska? And most importantly, WTF Tammy?

Choice of Games, when my obsession with this game has run its course, I will be coming back to your collection for more!

Survived the until the end on my first run, robot got compared to drunk Nate Silver.\n11/10 would invest in the robot industry, but then get arrested during the war, lead an Alaskan rebellion against the chinese, and then get robo surgery and celebrate the birthday of robo grandchild.\nI also screwed over some Greek dude.
This game has a great srory line with great branches to make your story and your robot unique, to your preferances.  This game is great if you have the imagination for this game.  I want more!

An interesting experience of how technology affect our lives and how it's changing and evolving in turn can change us. Our morals, our beliefs, etc. Circumstances change along with our technology, and just as our computers change and adapt to us, we adapt to them, raising a question of just how different we can be from each other. As robots come closer to being human, it also changes just what we think of as being necessary to claim to possess humanity. This game doles out some emotions, weighing relationships with humans against relationships with robots, and as the story progresses, it can be that you only know the robots are robots because the game reminds you of it.\n\nI also had a three-way with a human and a robot 10/10

The novel was excellent to play through, it allows you to choose what you want to do with your robot from the very beggining.\nIts complex to the point where I still have no idea how to get some of the endings.

I would very highly recommend this game, its is amazingly well wirtten and on every play through you get attached to the world you create. Its amazing and wonderous to play through time and time again, I would reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys building something up, and who enjoys seeing the outcomes of every decision.

Okay, a text based CYOA set in a (still) possible near future involving robots. If I say more on the contents then that will be a spoiler, so I'll refrain from doing so.\n\nWhat I can and will tell you though is that unlike other CYOA's of similar design this one is very... call it expansive. You really do feel like you areable to explore different branching storylines rather than ye standard three ending routes that many others seem plagued by. The sci-fi bits are extrapolated from current tech, so they are credible enough. Be aware though that it still manages to get bat-guano crazy here and there, but at the time of writing the review I'd say that if you want to try a good CYOA, this is the cream of the crop on Steam.

I found myself being asked deep philosophical questions that made me sit for a moment and ponder what life was really about. I cannot recommend this game enough. I have only played one branch of the many that i could have played and intend to explore this game further. Do yourself a favor if you take game decisions seriously and spend the money that would be needed to purchase a mcdonalds happy meal and by this beautiful game.

It's a nice change to see a great text based RPG on steam. Delve into the world of a mad scientist creating the first intelligent robot. A choose your own story game with vast amounts of replayability and hidden gems. Will you be good or evil? Smart or crude? Democratic or Fascist? This world is yours to create.
This is super fun! At first, I didn't think I would be able to get into this--because it was text-based--but oh man was i wrong! The story for this is absoluelty beautiful. High replay value.
I really enjoyed this and will run through it again at least once or twice. Great value for the cost.
I understood that my work would eventually strip me of my humanity in the toughing story. What I didn't know is that I would lose my humanity for real.. I couldn't stop playing until the end...

This game has given me multitudes of ideas. One, because I'm an artist this has fueled me up to create a portait of my robot, the characters in my imagination, and to create more bizzare creations. Two, as a robotics engineer student. I now have many ideas and clues as to what my next project will be.

Maybe, one day... I could build the robot I built in this game. That brings me joy.

(The robot I constructed looks, acts, and responds as a human would. They have a high empathy, grace and autonomy with empathy being the highest. Just trying to create a world where people accept our silicon relatives more or less as one of us.

I made some choices I wouldn't make twice, i have made some bad calls, but in the end, I was satisfied with that outcome and don't necessarily regret them. Great game, 10/10. gives all of the choices i would want and choices that matter. I don't play games like this often, but when I do, they are always a treat. (on a side note I actually think about stuff like this a lot, AI rights and stuff. and this game handles it perfectly, it gives you good choices for both sides of the argument and really makes you think. but even if you don't think about stuff like this like me, you will enjoy this. PS. I don't review things often but I am doing this right after my first play through, so let that show my satisfaction.)

reviewText: Everything you could ever possibly want in a cyoa game though it has one con. No save. So if you somehow ♥♥♥♥ up and game over out of the blue (Which I managed to do a total of 3 times) You have to start straight from the begining all over again. This game will make you laugh, make you cry, make you bloodthirsty, make you shameful. This game will change your view on robotics for life.

Note: minor spoilers included.

You are [pick a name], a robotic engineer destined for tough times, greatness, and death. So apply your imagination, and you will experience a wild and engaging life.

The literature is easy to follow and presents you with a large bank of options. Its world is believable and full of unexpected, yet very realistic, turns of events that are guided by each character's unique personality.

And though some characters may appear despicable during the first playthrough (I forced one, Mark, to commit suicide), each one's unique personality and background will emerge as you experiment with different options (As of my fifth playthrough, Mark has risen to be my favorite character). This game will make you second-guess yourself if you commit your emotions to it.

You may experience academic success or expulsion, career success or bankruptcy, triumph in war or defeat, friendship, romance, total control or love for a child, betrayal, several opportunities for vengeance, the death of a loved one, your own impending death, immortality, among other values. And by the end of the game, you may reflect on all that you sacrificed and be forced to re-evaluate each one's importance in your life.

Overall, I, a graphics worshipper who normally enjoy Assassin's Creed and Mortal Kombat, strongly recommend this non-graphic text-based journey. Who knows, it just might change your life.

If you like choose your own adventure books/games- this game is for you. (If you don't like reading, or robots, you probably shouldn't play this game)

The story can go a surprisingly wide number of ways (this is not like CYOA books found in elementary school libraries) and has a little bit of stat management to keep things interesting. There are a ton of achievements also, and some of them are not the most intuitive to get, so there's a ton ton ton of replay value (I've played it 6ish times as of writing this review). The beginning of most playthroughs are the same, so you get a bit faster as you go and know what early game choices you want to make, but the middle and endgames are quite varied.

I always end up getting really attached to my little robots- even when they try to kill me I still love them.

The writing is pretty good, the characters are interesting, and the choices you can make have a good spread between 'normal human decision' and 'absurd just for the hell of it' (with all variations in between as well).

Play this game, it's excellent.
Love it <3
All I wanted was to sit on a hill and watch the sunset with my robot bestfriend...

Touching, and dependig on the way you play can become a very personable experience. I do not regret getting this game what so ever. I'm looking forward to discovering more work like this, and going through this game again with a different goal/mindset.

This game is absolutely fantastic. You can have truly beautiful moments interacting with the fleshed-out characters (no matter what gender you or they are), or crush the world beneath the might of your robot armies. It's your choice!

reviewText:
A story for robo fanatics
Any robot fanatic should try this out, you get to put yourself in that dream situation that seems almost so impossible to reach. As an aspiring sci-fi writer, I found this to be a very inspriational and satisfying experience.

Possible spoilers below
There are many paths, but I've only taken one, and it was an emotional rollercoaster. I feel like I would spoil the experience by going with choices that would go against my true morals. Everyone's path will be different, and I mean everyone's.

The paths last around 2 - 3 hours each, so make sure you have some free time ready as there are no save options.

It's very well written and very much engaging. At no point did I really feel like I was being restricted by the author. Hell, I went into this hoping I could live a gay robot fantasy, and you bet I was able to live a gay robot fantasy. There aren't many experiences out there that let you do that. The really fun thing about this is that the author doesn't ask personal questions, it just rolls with your choices and your identity without berating you or questioning you. It's not intrusive, either: at no point did it ask about my orientation or preferences (aside from asking for my gender), it just let me do what felt right for me, which in this case was fall in love with a male robot. ++ for that haha

Overall it's a very good buy for robot fanatics, but I'm afraid that may really be the only audience this can appeal to. I can't see myself suggesting this to anyone outside of that niche. So if you like them bots (AND IF YOU ARE A DIRTY ROBOT FRICKER LIKE ME), this is a great experience.

reviewText: Enjoyable story with many branching plots and endings.. great deal for the price if you enjoy choose-your-own-adventure type stories.
After playing this game, I feel inspired to build a robot with free will in the real world.\n1000/10 Great game. Perfect for someone who likes to read (Because you will read. A lot.)

I swore that I would use my robots for the betterment of mankind, and never for military purposes. That they would be doctors, nurses, factory workers, anything any everything but weapons of war.

Then the War came.
And I turned my back on the morals I had set for my self.

I made humanoid robot soilders, and made them smart. Intelligent. They had the same sense of right and wrong I had... or, at least I used to have.
They were told to nuke large cities.
They refused, and set the nukes off in the Gobi Desert, saraficing them selfs to uphold the morals I had set for them. They even made a video for me.

The nukes made the chinese surrender, in fear of extermination.
I was declared a war hero.

I don't feel like a hero.

It's like one of those old Choose Your Adventure books you find in your school library when you're 10.\nExcept this gives you much more of a personalised story, so much that I almost shed a tear in one of my endings.\nIf you don't mind a bit of reading then I would highly suggest this.

I enjoyed this.  I've played it twice in the span of two days now and I'll probably play it a few more times just to try some of the other branches.  There are only two negative things I have to say, and I hope that maybe the dev can use steam updates to fix these: One, there's no options to control the display.  It would be great if I could increase the font size (since my eyes aren't so good) and also control the background and text color, or at least be able to invert it to white text on a black background.  And two, it's implied at the beginning that you can romance a robot and that it would be your first bot, but there doesn't actually seem to be a path to do this (forgive me and ignore this if there is I just haven't found it yet).  I get that you raised the first robot so there's some unfortunate implications towards incest there, but the growth period happens very quickly and isn't necessarily that much of a parental relationship depending on choices.  *shrug* I don't know, I just was much more attached to my first bot then the one that gets shoehorned into the end.

reviewText:
Well worth the cost.  Finished my first playthru and found it very immersive and enjoyable:

+ Very challenging options to choose from.  Many are nicely written and are clear what route I'm taking.  It was simlarly difficult to stay on a singular path (militaristic? empathic?) because the other options were often enticing.
+ Emotional surprises will dislodge you from your goal, provided you're not a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

- Some sections, particularly toward the end, seem hastily written and imbalanced with the buildup from previous sections.  For example, I had six or seven steps throughout my hostile takeover of a region, to then lose this progression (due to previous choices) and flee" within two more steps which ended in skipping ahead 10 years after my defeat.  I thought "That's it? I just threw in the towel?"
- Just a few inconsistencies
date: again toward the end.  Minor mistakes or fairly important details omitted.\n"

reviewText: Wow. I've just finished my first playthrough (took 2-3 hours), and my mind is blown. I've actually emailed Cory Doctorow to tell him about this game. I had a very touching, bittersweet ending. But if you like clever sci-fi combining genuine emotions, play this.

This interactive novel offered alot of choice. I really enjoyed reading this interactive novel and debating the philosophical questions and then the points it makes about a near future and the possibilities of sentinent AIs. As always I enjoy the 'Choice Of Games' interactive novels. I reccomend this book to anyone who is thinking of purchasing this book. This book in particular has a lot of replayability. The genre is Sci-fi/dystopian future. You make your own choices design your own character and robot. Fight or don't, live or die. The possibilites and choices are numerous. I do love the ability to customise and personalise the story I think that is very neat and this paves the way forward for the genre: 'interactive novels'.\n\nRating: 10/10  Reccommended? Yes definately a must buy. The developer and publisher never disapoints and the quality is superb!

reviewText: The amount of detail and number of directions the story can go in is amazing. I chose to develop relationships with my robot companions, and grew genuinely attached to them throughout the course of the game as I taught them what it means to be a person. That said, next time I'd like to try my hand at conquering everything with a robot army. That sounds just as fulfilling.

What can I say about this amazing story? It made me think, and interact on a level I haven't recieved by any game based on a first run without many discussions. I even named the robots I created after 2 human characters in Futurama (well one's a mutant). It was definately different, I was thrown curve balls all the time. I even had to deal with ♥♥♥♥ing Sarrah Palin, who practically caused WWIII with China (Not the neighbor she can see from here back yard, but China). You can even read my results of the whole story in this review if you'd like. Next run I do, I hope to die immediately. Have fun.


Chapter 1

On the day you first built F.R.Y., you awoke from a dream about a robot companion to head to the lab. Your graduate school advisor pressured you to make F.R.Y. more acceptable to the military. After some back and forth, you ended up making a metal bipedal robot with a masked head and humanoid hands.

Then you went back to your place to teach F.R.Y. some words.

Chapter 2

The next day, you hooked up F.R.Y.'s biodiesel engine and demoed for Elly. You then spent the afternoon perfecting F.R.Y.'s motor control and parts.

As months passed, you became busy teaching F.R.Y. about the world through movies and taking it to the park.

One day, however, Professor Ziegler claimed that F.R.Y. was not appealing enough to the military, and demanded you change it. You refused, and Professor Ziegler kicked you out of his lab.

In time, Mark Ali, a reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle, heard about F.R.Y. and asked for an interview. You agreed.

Chapter 3

You gave Mark an interview, and allowed Mark to come back to your place to interview F.R.Y..

Mark wrote an article that was generally positive about you and F.R.Y..

Mark's article attracted the attention of one robotObsession1987
date:
known in real life as Tammy Cooper.

Shortly thereafter, your father passed away. You resolved at his funeral to be remembered not only for your intellect, but for your kindness as well.

You joined Josh at U.S. Robots as his chief scientist.

Chapter 4

Your first potential client for U.S. Robots was Galen Medical, a surgical equipment company. They were happy with the state of your technology, and gave you a contract that allowed you to purchase a factory. That allowed you to build a robot factory in Alaska. You decided to use your own robots for your workforce, but leave humans in supervisory roles. When you finally shipped robots to Galen Medical, they were pleased with the robots you delivered.

Your business suffered a blow when Chinese companies, aided by Chinese government hackers, began to steal your technology. Your business was dealt a further blow when there was an explosion at your factory, caused by a bomb set by Tammy.

You were visited by a politician, Jacqueline Irons, who asked for a campaign donation. Despite your unhelpfulness, Irons won the presidency. The newly elected President enacted a series of protectionist bills that ultimately made China angry, and they cut off the U.S. supply of rare earths.

The tensions between the United States and China came to a head with the assassination of the Chinese Prime Minister in San Francisco. War followed shortly thereafter.

Chapter 5

Captain Rogers invited you to a military lab. There, you saw that Professor Ziegler was copying your work and passing it off as his own to the military. Captain Rogers asked you to join the country's war effort. You agreed, but specified that you only wanted to provide robots that were nonviolent in nature. But when your robots held a protest, you decided it wasn't worth it, and you backed out.

But you soon realized that you were not happy working for the government and quit.

An agent came to your place to try to get you to lure Elly there, because she was suspected of being a spy.

You found out through Mark that Juliet died while performing field tests of F.R.Y. V, Professor Ziegler's copy of your robot.

In the end, America lost the war, and the Chinese took over Alaska. Tired of seeing robots used for violent ends, you decided to create a truly beautiful robot.

Chapter 6B

You created a humanoid companion robot named LEELA, but you were fairly bad about allowing her to do anything fun. It seemed LEELA was interested romantically in you. When F.R.Y. and LEELA were attacked in the street, LEELA accidentally killed Tammy. LEELA was forced to spend time in jail, but suffered no permanent consequences.

Chapter 7

In 2049, you went to Surprise, Arizona to handle your mother's estate, since she had passed away recently. On returning to San Francisco, you had a brief stroke, followed by a vision of a robot companion -- the same one you saw thirty years before. In the hospital, the doctor told you you had Algernon's Disease, a rare disease that increased your intelligence, but came at the price of increasing seizures, comas, and possibly, death.

You chose to undergo surgery to remove the damaged tissue in your brain. You survived the surgery, thanks to your own robot surgical technology. You celebrated a birthday party with Dusa, F.R.Y.'s artificial child, and looked forward to celebrating many more.

reviewText:
NO SPOILERS
This game is the best $5 I've ever spent on something. Choice of robots is a sci-fi choose your own adventure novel with a huge scale. It's hard to describe just how emotionally attatched I became to the story.

As a student at MIT pursueing his or her doctorate, you will decide just how you want to make your robot... your passion project. Throughout the story, your decisions will escelate to change the world. After playing through the game for a first time, it became clear to me that the plot about robotics is really just a path to a story about life.

This is a story about love, loss, power, weakness, friendship, trust, betrayal, and much more.

I recommend this playable story to everyone who likes a story based game and dosn't mind an almost graphicless game!
10/10
The author appologizes for bad puns, 10/10

Loved this game.
It's very remniscent of the choose your own adventure books some might remember from their youths. But it's more than that, the adventure seems to be able to take multiple, very different twists and turns. I've just completed my second play through and other than presence of a robot, the story couldn't have been more different.
I picked this up very cheaply in a sale, for much less then the cost of a pint of lager. It would have been well worth it, even if I'd paid full price. I'm unlikely to still be playing this game in a month or even a week. But it's provided a full nights entertainment for me at a meagre cost and I may yet play it through once more, at the least.
I'll certainly be looking out for more of this companies games on steam in the future.

I'm not going to say anything about the story here, but If you find robots and artifical intelligence interesting, you will love this.\n\nIt took me more than 2 hours to reach the end once. However, from what I have seen so far, the story changes dramatically as you make choices, and you could play this again and again many times to see all the interesting plots it has to offer.

reviewText:
I have only just finished my play through of this mind-blowing game. In it you play a brilliant Robotics engineer--think Hiro from Big Hero 6--who kickstarts the age of robotics. From the off it is full of choices your character can make, besides being very well written by the author. The robot I first built, Ariel,--the game lets you choose practically every aspect of them--was a daughter of sorts, having chose to activate the tiny winged humanoid while looking at me and naming myself as 'Father' to her. As she discovered the world around her and slowly, sometimes awkwardly, grew into a young adult under my care, I grew incredibly attached to her and it actually moved me to tears on more than one occasion. It is the most powerful game I have played in a very long time and some of the most powerful story telling I have encountered in a very long time.

Imagine a Asimov classic only you are the main character. My first story depicted a relationship akin to that of Doctor Lanning and Sonny from the film I, Robot mixed up with a reversal of the plot to Bicentennial Man for the protagonist. I brought about a golden age where man and a new species of mechanical people coexist in peace in the wake of a violent Sino-American war.

You literally can follow many paths through the way you design your first robot and raise them and your relationships with the story's many side characters. Will you achieve world domination? End man as we know him/her or live the high life as a Tony Stark type character? So many routes you can go down. Will you become an American hero or a backer of the Chinese? I have heard that you and your first robot can even become a crime-fighting vigilante duo!--but don't hold me to that.

Such an amazing game which, in relation to all others, I can only describe as a Bethesda RPG in text format... but with far better plot and writing.

In fact, I'm so impressed I encourage all who read this to buy it--it's less than £5, and I have been moved so to create this review, which I rarely do.
Robot killed the president of the united states then laughed about it.  10/10

Wow, the story... the ending. It was like a short book, a very interesting short book.

I have to try different choices, though.

And I really recommend it, if you're into Multiple choices games.

I started this game new to robot games, and create your own adventure games. This is my experience so far.
I started out with attoning  for sins, Sin was creating robots with no empathy.
I then get pulled back to present. so I started creating robots. I then realised I was poor, so I got rich off my robot. I didn't mean to use the robot, but it was that or being homeless. So then, after becoming rich I started a business. Everything was so great, I was swimming in the green. Then suddenly China hacks into my businesses files and steals all of my blueprints. I thought everything would be okay if I cleared all my information before they could swipe it all but I was too late. Then before I know it, the Chinese were invading America with the robots built from my blueprints. That was a big uh-oh. From there I was ambushed by the FBI and thrown into prison. The Chinese secretly contacted me and helped me flee the country.
So anyways, this game is pretty interesting!
Rating: 9/10

This game is astoundingly brilliant. I say game, though, it truly is more of an interactive novel. It has almost endless possiblities. My robot named Tin Tin was sentient, singular, and graceful. This is a MUST play/read if you enjoy a good story. You are faced with a series of choices you must sit and ponder for eons. 11/10 have and will play again.\n

Best $1.5(or a bit less) ever spent!

Why?

-References to famous novelists(Most likely I didn't even notice all of them myself, some background knowledge of Science Fiction and Dystopia genre authors is highly recommended),)
-References to famous games(Old and new, good opportunity for some to expand their Steam library)
-Date simulator(To remind you that you suck at dating not only in real life. P/s: That's Exactly what happened to me)
-Life lessons(Like if you didn't have enough already)
-Decision making(Games like 'Life is Strange','The Wolf Among Us'(Highly recomend, as well as the comic series related the second game) are great for those who seek this kind of experience and 'Choice of Robots' is just at the level(=over 9000) not reachebable for mentioned games(maybe a few decades later, but not now))

Little bonus:
-Tons of emotions(Some episodes will actually make you feel relieved, angry, worried. They will make you feel that you actually anticipate the story(Guess who is the main hero))

I've nearly forgotten to mention the satisfaction you get after you finish the game for the first time!

I started out as a student who made a robot called durfinzartzopew. I worked for U.S. Robts, got married, saved the world, saved my mother's life, and was still alive by the end. Not to mention I got to live in a tiny apartment in Vancouver. Even without any graphics or audio, this game felt so cinematic I feel it should be turned into a movie. Every single second of the game I could picture what was going on in my head. Infact, being only text-based made me able to better visualize the game than if it had visual and auditory effects. This is the most sincere review that I made on Steam (not that I even usually review games), but I feel that Choice of Robots deserves it. Amen.

My wooden, bipedal, adorable robot named Sapling grew to resent humanity, which while scary, was still adorable because it was still only 3 feet tall.

Now I'm going to make an evil 8 legged monster to rule the world.

There's a lot of very different routes you can take in this game, for better and for worse.

Well worth the cost.  Finished my first playthru and found it very immersive and enjoyable:

+ Very challenging options to choose from.  Many are nicely written and are clear what route I'm taking.  It was simlarly difficult to stay on a singular path (militaristic? empathic?) because the other options were often enticing.
+ Emotional surprises will dislodge you from your goal, provided you're not a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

- Some sections, particularly toward the end, seem hastily written and imbalanced with the buildup from previous sections.  For example, I had six or seven steps throughout my hostile takeover of a region, to then lose this progression (due to previous choices) and flee" within two more steps which ended in skipping ahead 10 years after my defeat.  I thought "That's it? I just threw in the towel?"
- Just a few inconsistencies
date: again toward the end.  Minor mistakes or fairly important details omitted.\n"

Wow. I can tell you right now that you MUST buy this game.

I am fan of robots. Especially intelligent robots. They force us to imagine a world where humans come into contact with an intelligent species of our own creation and ask ourselves what we value in humanity and what we want represented in our creations.

This game perfectly captures what a make your own adventure" should be. There are choices that you make that you won't see the results for until much later. There will be times where you eagerly want to restart the game because of a choice leading you down a undesirable path. And yet you want to see if you can salvage the situation because you created your robot companion

I've played through so far only once but I already know that this is a great game with many routes to take. My journey was one through joy, heartbreak and horror at humanity itself and after swearing that I would put human relationships before any robots I accidentally caused the entire world to be run by robots. I refused modern medicine that I had created and chose the path of a slow death with the love of my life and our child, along with my first true creation, Sapling in a forest far from society and the constant reminder of the world that I created and rejected.\n\nMy first playthrough took three hours and had me gripped the entire time, not a game to pick up and put down as often as a phone.
Choices matter, and I genuinely enjoyed story (or rather, stories!) that I played through.

i have played this through multiple times, and got a different ending each time. the game is on point, it is a perfectly realised vision of the future. you care about you, your robots and the people around you, every choice you make doesnt just make a different section of dialogue apear, it affects your relationships with those people, you wealth, fame, and the robots grace, autonomy, militiary and empathy. this game is amazing. the acheivements are like puzzles, you have to make the right choices to unlock them. for $4.99 this game is an absolute bargain. the only glitch is, when you gain an acheivement, then go to the menu screen and return, another bubble will pop up. that is very minor\n9.5/10
This best written gaming experience I've ever had.

reviewText: I've only played through once so far, but this is a clever, well thought through game. It is exceedingly well-written, engaging, and even surprising in some of its turns. I can only assume it will continue to surprise me in further playthroughs.

The amount of detail and number of directions the story can go in is amazing. I chose to develop relationships with my robot companions, and grew genuinely attached to them throughout the course of the game as I taught them what it means to be a person. That said, next time I'd like to try my hand at conquering everything with a robot army. That sounds just as fulfilling.
This is a pretty neat game.  Minor spoiler from chapter 2:\nYou decide to bring DEATHLORD_5000 along to the knife-throwing event. What could go wrong? ""

This game is astoundingly brilliant. I say game, though, it truly is more of an interactive novel. It has almost endless possiblities. My robot named Tin Tin was sentient, singular, and graceful. This is a MUST play/read if you enjoy a good story. You are faced with a series of choices you must sit and ponder for eons. 11/10 have and will play again.\n

Best $1.5(or a bit less) ever spent!

Why?

-References to famous novelists(Most likely I didn't even notice all of them myself, some background knowledge of Science Fiction and Dystopia genre authors is highly recommended),)
-References to famous games(Old and new, good opportunity for some to expand their Steam library)
-Date simulator(To remind you that you suck at dating not only in real life. P/s: That's Exactly what happened to me)
-Life lessons(Like if you didn't have enough already)
-Decision making(Games like 'Life is Strange','The Wolf Among Us'(Highly recomend, as well as the comic series related the second game) are great for those who seek this kind of experience and 'Choice of Robots' is just at the level(=over 9000) not reachebable for mentioned games(maybe a few decades later, but not now))

Little bonus:
-Tons of emotions(Some episodes will actually make you feel relieved, angry, worried. They will make you feel that you actually anticipate the story(Guess who is the main hero))

I've nearly forgotten to mention the satisfaction you get after you finish the game for the first time!

This is one of the best that the choice of games series has to offer. Other games allow you to take different perspectives on things but take you through the same events nevertheless. Choice of robots however actually has world-changing choices and brings in some true feels and thought-provoking questions.\n\nMy only complaint was that I wish it was longer.

A text-based adventure, where you live your life as someone in which his/her fate will invole robot, and you have to choose your fate through tons of words.

Basically, this is a pretty good text-based game. Why? Imo, it is because the choices in this game makes sense in variuous situations, you can change your ways in a heartbeat depend on what you like to choose. The stories are nice, I have yet to play all kind, because I only like to choose what I like to choose, but overall it make you think the life you choose is real enough to feel good. If you are looking for good stories, this game can offer just that.

But the downside, as 5$, I think it lacks somethings, like, an artwork for ending or various turning point? Music plays when you love something to its climax? Honestly I don't think the price is worth with only text. Why? Cause there is some games out there offer just as good as this but with scenes and such. Maybe I'm just demanding.

But overall, I recomment this game, try this out, buy it, support so more game like this so it can be born and improved.

A deep, somewhat depressing game about humanity that allows you to craft memorable characters, play through great scenarios and ask yourself some pretty tough questions. and at least it has more choices and paths than any of the telltalle games.

An interesting experience of how technology affect our lives and how it's changing and evolving in turn can change us. Our morals, our beliefs, etc. Circumstances change along with our technology, and just as our computers change and adapt to us, we adapt to them, raising a question of just how different we can be from each other. As robots come closer to being human, it also changes just what we think of as being necessary to claim to possess humanity. This game doles out some emotions, weighing relationships with humans against relationships with robots, and as the story progresses, it can be that you only know the robots are robots because the game reminds you of it.\n\nI also had a three-way with a human and a robot 10/10

While often spoken of as one of the best Choice of Games titles, Choice of Robots is well worth the praise on the variety of choices and endings you do get by the end of it. While there are not thousands of different options I did feel like my playthrough was unique as no two of my friends ended up with the same exact endings. Choice of Robots is well written, funny and at times it knows where to poke at the tender bits of the heart, though in my opinion it does fall short due to it's raging hard-on for robots.

What can I say? I'm not a robot lover, at least not a LITERAL robot fellater.

At the end of the day Choice of Robots is a solid entry into the text adventure genre and it's one of those games that give the genre modern validity.

I've played through Choice of Robots about 3 times now, and each time has been a unique experience. I think I still have another round or 2 to go with this game to do all the stuff I want to try. Playing this game is like having a great sci-fi novel that's different everytime you read it, depending on what kind of adventure you feel like having. This is another strong 'Choice of games' game and makes me want to check out more of their stuff. Highly recommended for people who like this genre of game and robots.

If you like choose your own adventure books/games- this game is for you. (If you don't like reading, or robots, you probably shouldn't play this game)

The story can go a surprisingly wide number of ways (this is not like CYOA books found in elementary school libraries) and has a little bit of stat management to keep things interesting. There are a ton of achievements also, and some of them are not the most intuitive to get, so there's a ton ton ton of replay value (I've played it 6ish times as of writing this review). The beginning of most playthroughs are the same, so you get a bit faster as you go and know what early game choices you want to make, but the middle and endgames are quite varied.

I always end up getting really attached to my little robots- even when they try to kill me I still love them.

The writing is pretty good, the characters are interesting, and the choices you can make have a good spread between 'normal human decision' and 'absurd just for the hell of it' (with all variations in between as well).

Play this game, it's excellent.

reviewText:
This game is really, really good. I've been recently interested into choise-based games, and I think this game deserves to figure at top of this category.

There's no visuals or even music in this game, but trust me, it doesn't need it. The text alone perfectly manages to create its own universe. Though, it's only in English (it isn't my first langage, so I needed to search for vocabulary at some times) and you'll still need a good level to understand the game.

Through the whole game you've got plenty of choices, which leads to plenty of various endings. The choices you make really matters and have consequences, sometimes large-scale consequences. Several times I made decisions that I almost immediately regretted, but most of times I ended up with an ok (and even interesting) situation after all.

A nice thing is the different choices you make for your robot. You can choose how it will look, how it will call you, if you want your robot to be considered as male, female or something else, how you want to educate it ; and your decisions through the game will influence your robot's personality and relationship towards you. You can decide it will be a killing machine that'll obey your orders, or a nice and friendly robot which can even become your husband/wife/soul mate.
Absolutely amazing.

Anyway, this game is definitely worth a try.
No, not a try, a whole playthrough.

Wow. This isn't a game in the traditional sense, but my god is it good. You may start out with good intentions. You may start with evil intentions. You may even start with absolutly no clue what will happen, but one thing is set: eventually, no matter what, your plans will all go to ♥♥♥♥. I just wanted to make a friend, and started a world war. I then tried to make the coolest robot in existance, but only ended up alienating myself and my creation from the world.\n\nMassive replayability, deep storyline and a genuinly well written script. Wonderful game.
This game is great.

I enjoyed this.  I've played it twice in the span of two days now and I'll probably play it a few more times just to try some of the other branches.  There are only two negative things I have to say, and I hope that maybe the dev can use steam updates to fix these: One, there's no options to control the display.  It would be great if I could increase the font size (since my eyes aren't so good) and also control the background and text color, or at least be able to invert it to white text on a black background.  And two, it's implied at the beginning that you can romance a robot and that it would be your first bot, but there doesn't actually seem to be a path to do this (forgive me and ignore this if there is I just haven't found it yet).  I get that you raised the first robot so there's some unfortunate implications towards incest there, but the growth period happens very quickly and isn't necessarily that much of a parental relationship depending on choices.  *shrug* I don't know, I just was much more attached to my first bot then the one that gets shoehorned into the end.
never though i would get feels about a robots feels...

reviewText: I purchased this game a while back; I saw the reviews and thought it would be an incredible game for the price. Little did I know that you can play this game for free on its website.\nThe game itself was exceedingly boring. There is nothing to it other than clicking the mouse. Yes, this game is filled with difficult decisions that make a difference in the game's outcome, but it just seems pointless. The end of the game yields no satisfaction. You don't get the feeling of I just completed a game!". You read the last page presented to you
date: and then it gives you a link to the website nto try more of the developers' games.\nThis game is just hours of sitting and reading text. There isn't any cool backround music or soundtrack; no pictures to help visualize the sometimes vague descriptions; just text.\nI would never recommend that anyone purchase this game
recommended: ecspecially seeing as how it can be played for free."

reviewText:
*********************************************************[Minor Spoilers]************************************************************

This game was simply amazing to me. I named my robot Versatilis, the Latin for adapt, and the origin of the word versatile. I allowed it boundless autonomy and gave it empathy and grace. I resisted the military's urges to fund a weapon of destruction built with my technology and suffered financially and socially for it. But choosing the moral path seemed to pay off in a small fortune gained through creating precise surgical robots.

All was well until the Chinese decided to steal my designs and manufacture ripoffs of my robots, much like the way real-life ripoff products are made. I made a deal with an upcoming politician that I would fund her presidency if she made the Chinese pay. She did, and China waged war. Soon, to make up for the decision I made that ended up costing many American lives, and overturning my original decision to be a pacifist, I partnered with the U.S. Military to create nuclear powered humanoid fighting machines.

China still prevailed and conquered America, but with great loss on their part. Seeing this, I staged an uprising against the Chinese in Alaska, creating a sentient robot army so powerful, I could have ruled the world. After conquering Alaska, ruling shortly as an equal among my citizens, human and robot alike, I crushed China, ending them militarily, and economically. I destroyed them until they cowered against my armies like puppies against their master. Then, I checked myself, preventing myself from becoming a genocidal maniac. I disarmed my robots and gave Alaska back to the U.S., ending war for good with the nuclear deterrence I created.

Many years later, however, I physically pade the price of my years of waging war and replaced parts of my brain with AI hardware, acheiving ascension. Finally, I had an intillectual battle with the god Anubis, and won the right to continue living, regardless of my previous sins. ♥♥♥♥ you Anubis, you aren't taking my soul.

+++++++++++Awesomeness +++++++Heartwarming ++++++++++Replayability +++++++++++Awesomeness... Again.

It's an amazing game and I'd highly reccomend playing this at least a few times, with my two only complaints being while designing your robot, you have no clue what you're trying to achieve, and during the endings, things kind of rushed to conclude (At least the two endings I got did), so I really wasnt able to do everything I wanted to. Now, despite these things, while you may not feel really attached to the characters present, you still get really interested in your character and what you could potentially become. I thuroughly enjoyed this game/book.
My robots took over the world. +1

Okay, a text based CYOA set in a (still) possible near future involving robots. If I say more on the contents then that will be a spoiler, so I'll refrain from doing so.\n\nWhat I can and will tell you though is that unlike other CYOA's of similar design this one is very... call it expansive. You really do feel like you areable to explore different branching storylines rather than ye standard three ending routes that many others seem plagued by. The sci-fi bits are extrapolated from current tech, so they are credible enough. Be aware though that it still manages to get bat-guano crazy here and there, but at the time of writing the review I'd say that if you want to try a good CYOA, this is the cream of the crop on Steam.

It's a nice change to see a great text based RPG on steam. Delve into the world of a mad scientist creating the first intelligent robot. A choose your own story game with vast amounts of replayability and hidden gems. Will you be good or evil? Smart or crude? Democratic or Fascist? This world is yours to create.

Very good writing, quite interesting scripting. Totally worth its cost.
You can't save during a playthrough, it might seem annoying at first because it means if you have to close the game before you're finished, you'll have to quickly go through all the paragraphs and choices again, but it's quick enough to be only a minor annoyance and the innability to backtrack/reload on a choice really helps the immersion and involvement.
You know you've hit a sweet spot when even just naming the protagonists seem to have importance and relevance.

10/10, had to replay it twice right after reading it the first time, and i know i'll read it again with pleasure.
